{{Year box}} '''1828 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * 27 May — [[Jem Ward]] retains his English Championship with a 17 round victory over Jack Carter at Shepperton.<ref>[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/ward-j.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Jem Ward]. Retrieved on 6 November 2009.</ref>
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * Following the [[roundarm trial matches]] in 1827, [[Marylebone Cricket Club|MCC]] modifies Rule 10 of the [[Laws of Cricket]] to permit the bowler's hand to be raised as high as the elbow. An impasse results as, in practice, Sussex bowlers [[William Lillywhite]] and [[Jem Broadbridge]] continue to bowl at shoulder height and the umpires do not no-ball them. '''England''' * Most runs – [[Jem Broadbridge]] 316 @ 19.75 (HS 71) * Most wickets – [[Jem Broadbridge]] 46 (BB 5–?)
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Zoe (horse)|Zoe]] * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Cadland]] * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Cadland]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – [[Turquoise (horse)|Turquoise]] * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[The Colonel (horse)|The Colonel]]
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''Events''' * Anthony Brown, a [[Tyneside]] boat builder, develops the first crude riggers on [[sport rowing|rowing]] boats for racing.
==References== {{Reflist}}

[[Category:Sports by year]] [[Category:1828 in sports| ]]

{{Year box}} '''1853 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[Baseball]]== '''Events''' * The New York ''[[Sunday Mercury (New York)|Sunday Mercury]]'' publishes a box score for a [[New York Knickerbockers|Knickerbockers]]–Gothams baseball match, reprinted by the ''Clipper'' a few days later
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * 18 April — English champion [[Harry Broome]] defeats [[Henry Orme]] in the 31st round at Brandon to retain his title.<ref name="HB">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/broome-h.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Harry Broome]. Retrieved on 8 November 2009.</ref> * August — a scheduled bout between Broome and former champion [[William Perry (boxer)|William Perry]] does not come off; Broome has to pay forfeit and Perry claims the title, but his claim is not recognised and Broome retains the English Championship until 1856.<ref name="HB"/> * 12 October — [[Yankee Sullivan]] and [[John Morrissey]] meet to decide the Heavyweight Championship of America at Boston Corners, New York. According to reports, Morrissey is "badly beaten" but Sullivan leaves the ring after the 37th round and ignores the call of "time". As a result, the referee awards the fight to Morrissey, who holds the American Championship until 1859. Sullivan does not fight again but is subsequently arrested in San Francisco and sent to jail.<ref name="JM">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/morrisey.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – John Morrissey]. Retrieved on 8 November 2009.</ref> * Publication of the [[Revised London Prize Ring rules]]
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * '''England''' * Most runs – [[Jemmy Dean]] 372 @ 12.82 (HS 62) * Most wickets – [[James Grundy (cricketer)|James Grundy]] 87 @ 10.04 (BB 8–?)
==[[Horse racing]]== * [[West Australian (horse)|West Australian]] wins the English [[Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing|Triple Crown]] with a clean sweep of the 2000 Guineas, the Derby and the St Leger '''England''' * [[1853 Grand National|Grand National]] – [[Peter Simple (horse)|Peter Simple]] (for the second time, having previously won in 1849) * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – Mentmore Lass * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[West Australian (horse)|West Australian]] * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[West Australian (horse)|West Australian]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – Catherine Hayes * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[West Australian (horse)|West Australian]]
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * The [[Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]] is not held this year

{{Year box}} '''1918 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
''Note — many sporting events did not take place because of [[World War I]] or the [[1918 flu pandemic]]''
==[[American football]]== '''College championship''' * [[NCAA Division I FBS National Football Championship|College football national championship]] – [[Pittsburgh Panthers]] '''Professional football''' * Most teams shut down due to World War I and the flu pandemic; those that continue play are forced to delay the start of play until the middle of October or later * [[Dayton Triangles]] defeat [[Detroit Heralds]], both of whom continue full operations despite war and flu, to establish themselves as strongest team in the nation * [[1918 Buffalo Niagaras season|Buffalo Niagaras]] sign [[Tommy Hughitt]] for play in a citywide league, establishing a trend of expansion of top-level professional competition outside Ohio
==[[Association football]]== '''Europe''' * There is no major football in Europe due to [[World War I]]
==[[Australian rules football]]== '''VFL Premiership''' * [[Sydney Swans|South Melbourne]] wins the 22nd [[Australian Football League|VFL]] Premiership beating [[Collingwood Football Club|Collingwood]] 9.8 (62) to 7.15 (57) in the [[1918 VFL Grand Final]]. '''[[South Australian National Football League|South Australian Football League]]''': * not contested due to World War I '''[[West Australian Football League]]''': * 21 September: [[East Fremantle Football Club|East Fremantle]] 11.8 (74) defeat [[East Perth Football Club|East Perth]] 8.5 (53) for their tenth WAFL premiership.
==[[Bandy]]== '''Sweden''' * [[Allsvenskan and Elitserien (bandy)|Championship final]] – [[IFK Uppsala Bandy|IFK Uppsala]] 4–1 [[IK Sirius]] (replay following 2–2 draw)
==[[Baseball]]== '''World Series''' * 5–11 September — [[1918 Boston Red Sox season|Boston Red Sox]] (AL) defeats [[1918 Chicago Cubs season|Chicago Cubs]] (NL) to win the [[1918 World Series]] by 4 games to 2 '''Events''' * [[Babe Ruth]] leads the [[American League]] in [[home run]]s for the first time, hitting 11 * 2 September — professional baseball is curtailed to accelerate mobilisation for war
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * No world titles change hands in 1918 but [[Jack Dempsey]], with a series of knockouts including one against [[Battling Levinsky]], is now the main challenger to [[Jess Willard]]. '''Lineal world champions'''<ref>[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm Cyber Boxing Zone]</ref> * [[World Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[Jess Willard]] * [[World Light Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[Battling Levinsky]] * [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship – [[Mike O'Dowd]] * [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship – [[Ted "Kid" Lewis]] * [[World Lightweight Champion]]ship – [[Benny Leonard]] * [[World Featherweight Champion]]ship – [[Johnny Kilbane]] * [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship – [[Pete Herman]] * [[World Flyweight Champion]]ship – [[Jimmy Wilde]]
==[[Canadian football]]== '''Grey Cup''' * not contested due to [[World War I]]
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * There is no [[first-class cricket]] in England, Australia, South Africa or the West Indies due to [[World War I]]. A number of first-class matches are arranged in New Zealand but are not part of any official competition. '''India''' * [[Bombay Quadrangular]] – [[Hindus cricket team|Hindus]] shared with [[Parsees cricket team|Parsees]] '''New Zealand''' * [[Plunket Shield]] – ''not contested''
==[[Cycling]]== '''[[List of Tour de France winners|Tour de France]]''' * not contested due to [[World War I]] '''[[List of Giro d'Italia general classification winners|Giro d'Italia]]''' * not contested due to [[World War I]]
==[[Figure skating]]== '''World Figure Skating Championships''' * not contested due to [[World War I]]
==[[Golf]]== '''Events''' * All major championships are cancelled due to [[World War I]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1918 Grand National|Grand National]] – ''not held due to [[World War I]]'' * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Ferry (horse)|Ferry]] * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Gainsborough (horse)|Gainsborough]] * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – Gainsborough * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – [[My Dear (British horse)|My Dear]] * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – Gainsborough '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – Night Watch '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – Springside '''Ireland''' * [[Irish Grand National]] – Ballyboggan * [[Irish Derby Stakes]] – King John '''USA''' * [[1918 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – Exterminator * [[Preakness Stakes]] – ''not contested as a single race'' * [[Belmont Stakes]] – Johren
==[[Ice hockey]]== '''Stanley Cup''' * The temporary [[Toronto Arenas]] team defeats the [[1917–18 Montreal Canadiens season|Montreal Canadiens]] 10–7 to win the inaugural [[National Hockey League]] (NHL) championship * [[Vancouver Millionaires]] defeats [[Seattle Metropolitans]] 3–2 to win the [[Pacific Coast Hockey Association]] championship * 20–30 March — Toronto Arenas (NHL) defeats Vancouver Millionaires (PCHA) in the [[1918 Stanley Cup Finals]] by 3 games to 2 '''Events''' * 2 January — [[Montreal Wanderers]] disbands following destruction of its home venue by fire * [[Allan Cup]] is won by [[Kitchener Greenshirts]]
==[[Motor racing]]== '''Events''' * No major races are held anywhere worldwide due to [[World War I]]
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * [[The Boat Race|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]] – not contested due to [[World War I]]
==[[Rugby league]]== '''England''' * All first-class competitions are cancelled due to [[World War I]] '''Australia''' * [[New South Wales Rugby League premiership|NSW Premiership]] – [[South Sydney Rabbitohs|South Sydney]] (outright winner) '''New Zealand''' *[[1918 New Zealand rugby league season]]
==[[Rugby union]]== '''Five Nations Championship''' * [[Six Nations Championship|Five Nations Championship]] series is not contested due to [[World War I]]
==[[Speed skating]]== '''Speed Skating World Championships''' * not contested due to [[World War I]]
==[[Tennis]]== '''Australia''' * [[List of Australian Open Men's Singles champions|Australian Men's Singles Championship]] – not contested due to [[World War I]] '''England''' * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – not contested due to [[World War I]] * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Women's Singles Championship]] – not contested due to [[World War I]] '''France''' * [[List of French Open Men's Singles champions and finalists|French Men's Singles Championship]] – not contested due to [[World War I]] * [[List of French Open Women's Singles champions|French Women's Singles Championship]] – not contested due to [[World War I]] '''USA''' * [[US Open (tennis)|American Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Lindley Murray (tennis)|Lindley Murray]] (USA) defeats [[Bill Tilden]] (USA) 6–3 6–1 7–5 * [[US Open (tennis)|American Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Molla Bjurstedt Mallory]] (Norway) defeats [[Eleanor E. Goss]] (USA) 6–4 6–3 '''Davis Cup''' * 1918 International Lawn Tennis Challenge – ''not contested''

'''Portugal''' * [[1951–52 Primeira Divisão|Primeira Liga]] won by [[Sporting Clube de Portugal|Sporting C.P.]] ==[[Australian rules football]]== '''[[1952 VFL season|Victorian Football League]]''' * June 14: In an effort to promote the code outside its traditional strongholds in the southern and western states, the League holds a “National Day Round” of matches in selected interstate and country venues: [[Albury]], [[Euroa]], [[Yallourn]], [[Sydney]], [[Brisbane]] and [[Hobart]]. Despite flooding rains, attendances were high enough to deem the venture a success though it was never repeated. * [[Geelong Football Club|Geelong]] wins the 56th VFL Premiership by defeating [[Collingwood Football Club|Collingwood]] 13.8 (86) to 5.10 (40) in the [[1952 VFL Grand Final]] * [[Brownlow Medal]] awarded to [[Roy Wright (footballer)|Roy Wright]] ([[Richmond Football Club|Richmond]]) and [[Bill Hutchison (footballer)|Bill Hutchison]] ([[Essendon Football Club|Essendon]]){{ref label|retrospective|a|a}} '''[[South Australian National Football League]]''' * October 4: [[North Adelaide Football Club|North Adelaide]] beat [[Norwood Football Club|Norwood]] 23.15 (153) to 6.9 (45) in the most one-sided SANFL Grand Final until 2004. * [[Magarey Medal]] awarded to [[Len Fitzgerald]] ([[Sturt Football Club|Sturt]]) '''[[West Australian Football League|Western Australian National Football League]]''' * October 11: {{WAFL SF}} win their sixth premiership beating {{WAFL WP}} 12.19 (91) to 10.10 (70) * [[Sandover Medal]] awarded to [[Steve Marsh (footballer)|Steve Marsh]] (South Fremantle) ==[[Baseball]]== * January 31 – The [[National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum|Hall of Fame]] [[Baseball Hall of Fame balloting, 1952|elects two new members]] – [[Harry Heilmann]], with 203 votes, and [[Paul Waner]] with 195. Waner, a .333 career hitter, rapped out 3,152 hits and struck out just 376 times in 9,459 career at–bats. Heilmann was similarly skilled with the bat, winning four batting titles [[Detroit Tigers|with the Tigers]] and finishing his career with a .342 average * [[1952 World Series|World Series]] – [[1952 New York Yankees season|New York Yankees]] win 4 games to 3 over [[1952 Brooklyn Dodgers season|the Brooklyn Dodgers]] ==[[Basketball]]== * [[NCAA Men's Basketball Championship]] – ** Kansas wins 80–63 over St. John's '''[[1952 NBA Finals|NBA Finals]]''' *[[1951–52 Minneapolis Lakers season|Minneapolis Lakers]] win four games to three over [[1951-52 New York Knicks season|the New York Knicks]] ==[[Boxing]]== * June 25 at [[Yankee Stadium (1923)|Yankee Stadium]], [[Joey Maxim]] defeats [[Sugar Ray Robinson]] by knockout to retain his world light heavyweight title. revision.text:
{{Black Power sidebar}} The '''1972 Olympics Black Power Salute''' was a political protest by two US Olympic runners [[Vincent Matthews (athlete)|Vincent Matthews]] and [[Wayne Collett]] during the [[1972 Summer Olympics]] at the [[Olympiastadion (Munich)|Olympic Stadium]] in [[Munich]], [[West Germany]]. This event is sometimes referred to as "The Forgotten Protest."{{cite web|url=http://speedendurance.com/2011/02/01/vince-matthews-and-wayne-collette-1972-the-forgotten-protest/|title=Vince Matthews and Wayne Collett 1972 – The Forgotten Protest?|author=Jimson Lee|work=SpeedEndurance.com}} This event came four years after the [[1968 Olympics Black Power salute]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/04/24/sport/olympics-norman-black-power/|title=The third man: The forgotten Black Power hero|author=James Montague, CNN|date=24 April 2012|work=CNN}} ==Before the games== Matthews was a 1968 Olympian who had retired.{{cite web|url=https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/ma/vince-matthews-1.html|title=Vince Matthews|work=Olympics at Sports-Reference.com}} He was frustrated by problems that included having to pay his own travel to the US Trials.{{cite book | last=Hartmann | first=D. | title=Race, Culture, and the Revolt of the Black Athlete: The 1968 Olympic Protests and Their Aftermath | publisher=University of Chicago Press | year=2004 | isbn=978-0-226-31855-4 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KNvIe2JE0vIC&pg=PA241 | ref=harv | accessdate=2015-04-17}} ==Protest== Both runners refused to stand for the US National Anthem.{{cite book | last=Schiller | first=K. | last2=Young | first2=C. | title=The 1972 Munich Olympics and the Making of Modern Germany | publisher=University of California Press | series=Weimar and now | year=2010 | isbn=978-0-520-26213-3 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yxEQEqnXdRAC&pg=PT134 | ref=harv | accessdate=2015-04-17}} They subsequently stroked their beards, and twirled their medals as they left the stadium. The crowd booed both runners for their display.{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/mar/17/local/la-me-wayne-collett18-2010mar18|title=Wayne Collett dies at 60; UCLA sprinter won silver medal at '72 Olympics|work=latimes}} ==Media reaction== The [[Associated Press]] noted that the casual behavior of Matthews and Collett during the playing of the anthem as "disrespectful," and described the conduct as follows:
Collett, bare-footed, leaped from the No. 2 tier to the No. 1 stand beside his teammate. They stood sideways to the flag, twirling their medals, with Matthews stroking his chin. Their shoulders slumped, neither stood erect nor looked at the flag. ... As whistles and catcalls continued, Collett raised a clenched fist to the crowd before entering the portal of the dressing room.{{cite news|title=Milburn, Matthews Win Gold, But U.S. Trails|newspaper=Sarasota Herald-Tribune|date=September 8, 1972|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=gpwcAAAAIBAJ&sjid=mWYEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5359,2754393&dq=wayne+collett&hl=en}}
Robert Markus reported in the Chicago Tribune on September 9, 1972{{cite web|url=http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1972/09/09/page/229/|title=Chicago Tribune - Historical Newspapers|publisher=}}
[Matthews] was angry at Coach Bill Bowerman-as most of the U.S. trackmen seem to be-because Bowerman had hinted he would like to remove him from the place he had earned in the 400-meter field. He was angry that he had been forced to train on his own in unsuitable facilities, had to travel 4 or 5 times from N.Y. to the west coast in order to get any kind of competition, and had been put down by some of the press as a drag on America's hopes for a 400-meter sweep.
The Chicago Tribune further reported{{cite web|url=http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1972/09/09/page/227/|title=Chicago Tribune - Historical Newspapers|publisher=}}
Matthews said his and Collett's actions were directed at the U.S. coaching staff, not the flag or the National Anthem. "We were just mad about a lot of things. We didn't think it would blow up like this. We were asked to apologize. I'm not really sorry for what I did. I'm sorry for the way people took it [hoots and whistles from the stands when the anthem finished]. What I tried to get across to the Olympic Committee was if it was pre-meditated I could have done something better than that. It was just something that happened. We didn't realize the implications to the people in the stands."
In an interview after the medal ceremony with the [[American Broadcasting Company]], Collett said the [[national anthem]] meant nothing to him.{{cite news|author=Chuck Johnson|title=Matthews, Collett Barred for Conduct on Victory Stand|newspaper=The Milwaukee Journal|date=September 8, 1972|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=cMAdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=oygEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7196,4127118&dq=wayne+collett&hl=en}} He explained that he had felt unable to honor the anthem, because of the struggle faced by [[African American]]s at the time: "I couldn't stand there and sing the words because I don't believe they're true. I wish they were. I believe we have the potential to have a beautiful country, but I don't think we do." The pair were banned from future Olympic competition by the IOC; since [[John Smith (sprinter)|John Smith]] had pulled a hamstring 80 meters into the final while leading and had been ruled unfit to run, the USA were now unable to field a team in the [[4 × 400 metres relay|4 × 400 m relay]] and were forced to scratch from the event. ===Athlete statements===
I wasn't acting any differently than I usually do, but we were like goldfish in a fishbowl, in front of all those people. If they wanted me to stand at attention, I could've probably done that, but it wouldn't be me, and I was led to believe that the Olympics was for the athlete. We consider ourselves athletes, not politicians, or marching bands. Our athletic competition was over, and we were both happy.{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/page2/s/merron/030205.html|title=ESPN.com - Page2 - Violating the Olympic spirit|work=go.com}}
==After the games== Matthews was banned from all future Olympic events.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JrEDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA32&lpg=PA32&dq=Vincent+Matthews+banned&source=bl&ots=njf4IVrOwi&sig=JH18ql10zlU9ayOguLiIDL6LvMg&hl=en&sa=X&ei=xF8uVY3-KsuKyATe4YGACA&ved=0CDoQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=Vincent%20Matthews%20banned&f=false%7ctitle=Jet%7cwork=google.com|title=Jet|work=google.com|accessdate=17 April 2015}} Both runners in fact received a lifelong ban from the IOC and the USOC. This banning likely cost the US medals in the 4x400. Both runners were eventually elected to the Black Olympian Hall of Fame.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3KdbR4eqgfEC&pg=PA151&lpg=PA151&dq=Vincent+Matthews+Wayne+Collett&source=bl&ots=PiCNVyOHE4&sig=X8bd-DGcrE-KxhtW7acoiCA9AME&hl=en&sa=X&ei=UmIuVYuuEouoyQSArYHIAQ&ved=0CD0Q6AEwCDgK#v=onepage&q=Vincent%20Matthews%20Wayne%20Collett&f=false|title=Black Enterprise|work=google.com}} IOC President [[Avery Brundage]] stated the actions of Matthews and Collett made for a "disgusting display."{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/wayne-collett-athlete-who-staged-a-black-power-protest-at-the-1972-olympic-games-1956018.html|title=Wayne Collett: Athlete who staged a Black Power protest at the 1972 Olympic Games|work=The Independent}} This display by the athletes would be overshadowed by the [[Munich massacre]]. Collett went on to become a lawyer. In 2011, Matthews was elected to the USATF Hall of Fame.{{cite web|url=http://www.usatf.org/halloffame/TF/showBio.asp?HOFIDs=249|title=USATF - Hall of Fame|work=usatf.org}} ==Footnotes== {{reflist|2}} [[Category:1972 in the United States|Olympics Human Rights Salute, 1968]] [[Category:1972 Summer Olympics|Olympics Human Rights Salute, 1968]] [[Category:1972 in Germany]] [[Category:Civil rights protests]] [[Category:Counterculture of the 1960s]] [[Category:Black Power]] [[Category:Hand gestures]] [[Category:History of Munich]] [[Category:History of West Germany]] [[Category:Politics and race in the United States]] [[Category:Protests in Mexico]] [[Category:Olympic Games controversies]] [[Category:Anti-racism]] [[Category:Politics and sports]] [[Category:Salutes]] [[Category:1972 works|Olymp]] [[Category:1972 in art|Olymp]] [[Category:1970s photographs]]

lat_deg = 48.8567 | lon_deg = 2.3508 }} {{Location map~ | France | label = Stade Vélodrome | position = top | marksize = 7 | link = Stade Vélodrome | lat_deg = 43.269722 | lon_deg = 5.395833 }} {{Location map~ | France | label = Civaux | position = top | marksize = 7 | link = Civaux Nuclear Power Plant | lat_deg = 46.456667 | lon_deg = 0.652778 }} }} From March to May 1998, a terror plot against the [[1998 FIFA World Cup]] in France was uncovered by European law enforcement.<ref name="LAT">{{Cite news|title=European Police Raids Target World Cup Terrorist Threat|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1998/may/27/sports/sp-53951|work=The Los Angeles Times|date=27 May 1998}}</ref><ref name="GlobalTerrorism1998">{{Cite journal|title=Europe Overview|journal=Patterns of Global Terrorism: 1998|url=https://fas.org/irp/threat/terror_98/europe.htm|publisher=[[Bureau of Counterterrorism|Office of the Coordinator for Counterterrorism]] (United States Department of State)|date=April 1999}}</ref> More than 100 people were arrested in seven countries as a result of the plot.<ref name="ESPN">{{Cite news|first=Simon|last=Kuper|authorlink=Simon Kuper|title=Is football facing a new age of stadium terrorism after Paris attacks?|url=http://www.espnfc.com/european-championship/74/blog/post/2715900/paris-attacks-and-a-new-age-of-stadium-terrorism|work=ESPN FC|date=18 November 2015}}</ref> Organised by the Algerian [[Armed Islamic Group of Algeria|Armed Islamic Group]] (GIA) and backed by [[al-Qaeda]] leader [[Osama bin Laden]], the plot is thought to have targeted the [[1998 FIFA World Cup Group G#England vs Tunisia|England–Tunisia match]] on 15 June 1998, and involved infiltrating the [[Stade Vélodrome]] in [[Marseille]] in order to attack players and spectators during the game, attack the hotel in [[Paris]] hosting the [[United States men's national soccer team|United States national team]], and finally hijacking an aircraft and crashing it into the [[Civaux Nuclear Power Plant]] near [[Poitiers]].<ref name="ESPN"/>
==Raids and arrests== The original suspect of the plot was French-Algerian [[Farid Melouk]], who had previously been sentenced ''[[Trial in absentia|in absentia]]'' to seven years in prison in France for his connection to the [[1995 Paris Métro and RER bombings]].<ref name="NYT">{{Cite news|title=World News Briefs; Belgians Arrest Suspect In Paris Bombings|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/06/world/world-news-briefs-belgians-arrest-suspect-in-paris-bombings.html|work=The New York Times|date=6 March 1998}}</ref><ref name="Depeche">{{Cite news|title=Bruxelles : échec au réseau du GIA|url=http://www.ladepeche.fr/article/1998/03/06/186734-bruxelles-echec-au-reseau-du-gia.html|work=La Dépêche du Midi|date=6 March 1998|language=French}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Anschläge bei Fußball-WM?|url=http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/d-7838193.html|work=Der Spiegel|date=16 March 1998|language=German}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Silhouette|url=http://www.la-croix.com/Archives/1998-11-10/Silhouette-_NP_-1998-11-10-462539|work=La Croix|date=10 November 1998|language=French}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Le repaire belge du terrorisme|url=http://www.lalibre.be/actu/international/le-repaire-belge-du-terrorisme-51b874c6e4b0de6db9a638e6|work=La Libre Belgique|date=14 September 2001|language=French}}</ref> Melouk had reportedly been tracked by intelligence services following his entry into [[Belgium]], where he was found to be in contact with [[Ahmed Zaoui]] and a GIA-linked [[Brussels]] mosque.<ref>Robinson, 2002, p. 172</ref> On 3 March, after two weeks of surveillance, fifty police officers stormed a house where Melouk was staying with others involved in the plot.<ref name="Robinson173">Robinson, 2002, p. 173</ref> Ten people including Swedish and Danish nationals were arrested in the 12-hour siege, amid a series of anti-terrorism raids in Belgium.<ref name="GlobalTerrorism1998"/><ref name="NYT"/><ref name="Depeche"/> Large amounts of liquid explosives were found during the raid, as well as detonators, a [[AK-47|Kalashnikov rifle]], several handguns and thousands worth of [[United States dollar|US dollars]] in cash.<ref name="Robinson173"/><ref name="FFI">{{Cite journal|first1=Brynjar|last1=Lia|authorlink1=Brynjar Lia|first2=Åshild|last2=Kjøk|date=8 August 2001|title=Islamist Insurgencies, Diasporic Support Networks, and their Host States: The Case of the Algerian GIA in Europe 1993–2000|url=https://www.ffi.no/no/Rapporter/01-03789.pdf|publisher=[[Norwegian Defence Research Establishment]] (FFI)|pages=41–43}}</ref> In addition, a large number of documents, brochures and maps relating to the World Cup were retrieved.<ref name="Robinson173"/><ref name="FFI"/> More explosives were uncovered in a follow-up raid of another house.<ref name="GlobalTerrorism1998"/>
The March raid was part of a joint security operation between Belgium, France, Sweden, Italy and the United Kingdom.<ref name="GlobalTerrorism1998"/> Despite initial Belgian claims denying links to any plot against the World Cup, the plot was later confirmed by the French counter-intelligence chief.<ref name="PBS">{{Cite news|title=Chronology: The Plots|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/front/special/cron.html|work=Frontline|publisher=PBS|date=25 January 2005}}</ref> Melouk was sentenced to 9 years in prison for charges including attempted murder.<ref name="PBS"/> In early May, eight suspected militants linked to the plot were arrested in the United Kingdom.<ref name="FFI"/><ref>Robinson, 2002, p. 180</ref>
On 26 May, nearly 100 people were detained in coordinated operations across France, Belgium, Italy, Switzerland and Germany.<ref name="LAT"/><ref name="GlobalTerrorism1998"/><ref name="PBS"/> In France, 53 men including Algerian, French and Tunisian nationals suspected of links to ex-GIA commander [[Hassan Hattab]] were detained across 43 locations, including in Marseilles, Paris, [[Lyon]] and [[Corsica]]; around 25 were arrested and charged or deported.<ref name="FFI"/><ref>Robinson, 2002, pp. 190–191</ref> Five Algerians were arrested in Germany after raids across several cities, ten in Belgium, two in Switzerland, six in Italy, and many more detained.<ref name="FFI"/><ref>Robinson, 2002, pp. 188–189</ref> French Interior Minister [[Jean-Pierre Chevènement]] said on French television after the arrests that investigators had found evidence of plots to attack the World Cup.<ref name="LAT"/> Islamist paraphernalia and $150,000 in cash were found during the raids, but no explosives or arms.<ref name="LAT"/><ref name="FFI"/> Some police sources have said that a goal of the May raids was to crush GIA support networks.<ref name="FFI"/> According to counter-terrorism magistrate [[Jean-Louis Bruguière]], the May raids were a preventive measure to protect the tournament.<ref name="GlobalTerrorism1998"/>
==Plot and aftermath== The plot involved terrorists infiltrating the Stade Vélodrome in Marseille as stadium crew, in order to attack English players and spectators during the England-Tunisia match on 15 June.<ref name="ESPN"/> Terrorists had reportedly planned to blow up the England substitute bench (targeting youngsters [[David Beckham]] and [[Michael Owen]]), shoot English players and throw grenades into the stands.<ref name="ESPN2">{{Cite news|first=Harry|last=Harris|title=England terrorist plot revealed|url=http://www.espnfc.com/story/683732/england-football-team-escaped-terrorist-attack-at-1998-world-cup|work=ESPN FC|date=8 October 2009}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|first=Laurent|last=Dubois|year=2010|title=Soccer Empire: The World Cup and the Future of France|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0tyBmBcbZIMC&lpg=PP1&hl=no&pg=PT181#v=onepage&q&f=false|publisher=University of California Press|page=181|isbn=9780520259287}}</ref> Other terrorists were then to storm the United States national team's hotel in Paris and attack American players watching the game there.<ref name="ESPN"/> The attacks would be followed by another group of terrorists who would hijack an aircraft and crash it into the Civaux Nuclear Power Plant near Poitiers, causing a [[nuclear meltdown]].<ref name="ESPN"/>
The details or even existence of the plot was kept secret from managers, players and the media, but was known to security including [[The Football Association|FA]] staff.<ref name="ESPN2"/> In 2009, England manager in 1998 [[Glenn Hoddle]] revealed that he had only been informed of the plot "years later", while FA Director of Communications during 1998 [[David Davies (football administrator)|David Davies]] said that he had been informed of the plot before the match by FA Head of Security Brian Hayes.<ref name="ESPN2"/> The match was otherwise marred by supporter riots in Marseilles, with British vehicles being bricked while bottles were thrown across the streets, causing police to use tear gas as large numbers of supporters were injured and arrested.<ref name="ESPN2"/>
Although organised by GIA operatives, the plot reportedly had the backing and support of al-Qaeda leader Osama bin Laden.<ref>{{Cite book|editor-first1=Nicholas John|editor-last1=Cull|editor-first2=David Holbrook|editor-last2=Culbert|editor-first3=David|editor-last3=Welch|first=Nicholas J.|last=Cull|year=2003|title=Propaganda and Mass Persuasion: A Historical Encyclopedia, 1500 to the Present|chapter=Osama bin Laden|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Byzv7rf6gL8C&lpg=PP1&hl=no&pg=PA222#v=onepage&q&f=false|publisher=ABC-CLIO|page=222|isbn=9781576078204}}</ref> According to bin Laden biographer [[Yossef Bodansky]], the World Cup plot being foiled was one of the reasons for "dormant terrorist networks" responsible for the August [[1998 United States embassy bombings]] being "reactivated". The attacks killed over 200 and wounded more than 4,000.<ref name="ESPN"/><ref>{{Cite news|first=Simon|last=Kuper|title=The World's Game Is Not Just A Game|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/05/26/magazine/the-world-s-game-is-not-just-a-game.html?pagewanted=all|work=The New York Times Magazine|date=26 May 2002}}</ref>
A terror plot against the [[UEFA Euro 2000]] was discovered after Dutch intelligence intercepted calls made between GIA operatives from inside French prisons.<ref name="ESPN2000">{{Cite news|title= Gun guard on French soccer stars|url=http://www.espnfc.com.au/euro2000/news/20000620frathreat.html|work=ESPN Soccernet|date=20 June 2000}}</ref> Three men were detained in French prisons as a result of the plot, and three were subsequently arrested in the Netherlands.<ref name="ESPN2000"/> One of the French prisoners detained for the plot was Adel Mechat, who served 6 years after having been arrested in Germany and extradited to France as part of the 1998 World Cup raids.<ref name="ESPN"/><ref name="ESPN2000"/>
The night before the first ever football match between France and Algeria in October 2001, police seized explosives and arrested four Islamist militants suspected of having targeted the game after a phone call had been intercepted with warnings to stay away from the [[Stade de France]]. Other items retrieved included bulletproof vests and explosives manuals.<ref name="PBS"/><ref name="Telegraph">{{Cite news|title=International Football: Seventeen held as Algerian fans invade pitch|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/international/3014255/International-Football-Seventeen-held-as-Algerian-fans-invade-pitch.html|work=The Telegraph|date=7 October 2001}}</ref> The match itself became marred with controversy, and was eventually stopped with 15 minutes left playing after Algerian fans stormed the field.<ref name="PBS"/><ref name="Telegraph"/>

Danish riot vehicle support | dfen = }} The '''2009 Malmö Davis Cup riots''' were anti-[[Israel]] riots in the Swedish city of [[Malmö]] against a [[Davis Cup]] tennis match [[2009 Davis Cup World Group#Sweden vs. Israel|between Sweden and Israel]] on 7 March 2009.{{Cite news|title=Anti-Israel protest staged at Sweden tennis match|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-sweden-davis-protests-idUSTRE5261R220090307|publisher=Reuters|date=7 March 2009}}{{Cite news|title=Anti-Israel protest turns violent|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/europe/2009/03/200937141836935467.html|work=Al Jazeera|date=7 March 2009}} ==Background== In February, the tennis match had been decided by Malmö's [[Red-Greens (Sweden)|red-green]] city coalition to be closed to the public, a decision that was heavily criticised by the [[International Tennis Federation]] (ITF).{{Cite news|title=Sweden-Israel Davis Cup to go ahead without public|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/02/24/sports/24iht-tennisdavis24.20403874.html|work=The New York Times|date=24 February 2009}}{{Cite news|first=Owen|last=Gibson|title=Fans banned from Israel's Davis cup tie |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2009/feb/28/tennis-israel-gaza-davis-cup|work=The Guardian|date=28 February 2009}} The Mayor of Malmö, [[Ilmar Reepalu]] personally said he thought the game should not be played at all, and the decision was thus considered to be more politically motivated than out of security concerns.{{Cite news|title=Davis Cup Double Fault: Israel-Sweden Fan Lockout Stirs Controversy|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/europe/davis-cup-double-fault-israel-sweden-fan-lockout-stirs-controversy-a-611738.html|work=Der Spiegel|date=6 March 2009}} ==Riots== In anticipation of protests around 1,000 police officers sanctioned off a large area around the Baltic Hall tennis stadium to keep protesters and rioters away. A reported 170 truck loads of pavement stones were transported out of the area before the protests, and three schools were closed.{{Cite news|first=Ole|last=Rothenborg|title=Stenhögar kan stoppa polisinsatsen|url=http://www.dn.se/nyheter/sverige/stenhogar-kan-stoppa-polisinsatsen/|work=Dagens Nyheter|date=4 March 2009|language=Swedish}} In addition, for the first time in history, riot vehicles were brought in from [[Denmark]].{{Cite news|first=Jacob|last=Lund|title=Frykter sammenstøt i Sverige|url=http://www.vg.no/nyheter/utenriks/sverige/frykter-sammenstoet-i-sverige/a/551211/|work=Verdens Gang|date=7 March 2009|language=Norwegian}} The match was initially met with protest of around 6,000 to 7,000 anti-Israel demonstrators, with speeches held by the leader of the [[Left Party (Sweden)|Left Party]], [[Lars Ohly]], who while wearing a Palestinian scarf was seen holding a map of Palestine with Israel eradicated.{{Cite news|first=Karl-Johan|last=Karlsson|title=Här raderar Lars Ohly Israel|url=http://www.expressen.se/nyheter/har-raderar-lars-ohly-israel/|work=Expressen|date=27 February 2010|language=Swedish}}{{Cite news|title=Demonstranterna till attack mot polisen i Malmö|url=http://www.expressen.se/kvp/demonstranterna-till-attack-mot-polisen-i-malmo/|publisher=Expressen/TT|date=7 March 2009|language=Swedish}} The demonstrators were joined by several hundred militants of which around 200 to 300 began attacking police with stones, fireworks and paint bombs.{{Cite news|first=Pål|last=Stokka|title=Anti-israelsk demonstrasjon sporet av i Malmø|url=http://www.dagbladet.no/2009/03/07/nyheter/utenriks/sverige/5181651/?www=1|work=Dagbladet|date=7 March 2009|language=Norwegian}} The anti-Israel rioters included [[Antifascistisk Aktion|AFA]] [[Anti-fascism|anti-fascists]], militant [[Islamism|Islamists]], organised [[Neo-Nazism|neo-Nazis]],{{Cite news|first1=Linda|last1=Hjertén|first2=Per-Ola|last2=Ohlsson|title=100 omhändertagna efter demonstrationen|url=http://www.aftonbladet.se/nyheter/article11689300.ab|work=Aftonbladet|language=Swedish|date=7 March 2009}}{{Cite news|title=Godmorgon, världen!: Söndag 8 mars|url=https://sverigesradio.se/sida/artikel.aspx?programid=438&artikel=2682135|publisher=Sveriges Radio|date=6 March 2009|language=Swedish}}{{Cite news|first=David Nannini|last=Nilsson|title=Nazister väntas till tennismatch|url=http://www.aftonbladet.se/nyheter/article11685560.ab|work=Aftonbladet|date=5 March 2009|language=Swedish}}{{Cite news|first=Daniel|last=Poohl|title=Nazister i demonstration mot Davis Cup-match|url=http://expo.se/2009/nazister-i-demonstration-mot-davis-cup-match_2482.html|publisher=Expo|date=5 March 2009|language=Swedish}} as well as activists from neighbouring countries.{{Cite news|first=Richard|last=Lööf|title=SVT:s Richard Lööf rapporterar: "Malmö sämsta tänkbara för högriskmatch"|url=http://www.svt.se/nyheter/inrikes/svt-s-richard-loof-rapporterar-malmo-samsta-tankbara-for-hogriskmatch|publisher=SVT|date=6 March 2009|language=Swedish}}{{Cite news|first=Kenan|last=Habul|title=De vill göra allt för att stoppa matchen|url=http://www.sydsvenskan.se/malmo/de-vill-gora-allt-for-att-stoppa-matchen/|work=Sydsvenskan|date=7 March 2009|language=Swedish}} Police eventually detained around 100 rioters, arresting ten.{{Cite news|title=Swedish teen jailed for Davis Cup protest|url=http://www.jta.org/2009/04/29/news-opinion/world/swedish-teen-jailed-for-davis-cup-protest|publisher=JTA|date=29 April 2009}} An additional eighteen rioters were later identified and put on trial for their part in the riots,{{Cite web|title=Polis angreps av autonoma aktivister vid Davis Cup-match|url=http://www.sakerhetspolisen.se/publikationer/fallstudier-och-artiklar-fran-arsbocker/politisk-extremism/-polis-angreps-av-autonoma-aktivister-vid-davis-cup-match.html|publisher=[[Swedish Security Service]]|language=Swedish|accessdate=10 February 2016}} with several convictions.{{Cite news|first=Daniel|last=Persson|title=Fängelse för tenniskravaller|url=http://www.sydsvenskan.se/malmo/fangelse-for-tenniskravaller/|work=Sydsvenskan|date=29 April 2009|language=Swedish}}{{Cite news|title=Fortsatt rättegång om tennisbråk|url=http://www.sydsvenskan.se/malmo/fortsatt-rattegang-om-tennisbrak/|publisher=Sydsvenskan/TT|date=2 June 2009|language=Swedish}}{{Cite news|first=Mikael|last=Funke|title=Fängelse efter tenniskravaller|url=http://www.sydsvenskan.se/malmo/fangelse-efter-tenniskravaller/|work=Sydsvenskan|date=25 February 2010|language=Swedish}}{{Cite news|first=Joakim|last=Palmkvist|title=Tre tonåringar dömda för Davis Cup-kravaller|url=http://www.sydsvenskan.se/malmo/tre-tonaringar-domda-for-davis-cup-kravaller/|date=10 September 2010|language=Swedish}} ==Aftermath== The decision to close the tennis match to the public resulted in Malmö being banned from hosting tennis matches by the ITF for five years.{{Cite news|title=Sweden punished for Israel Davis Cup lockout|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/tennis/daviscup/5095836/Sweden-punished-for-Israel-Davis-Cup-lockout.html|work=The Telegraph|date=2 April 2009}} In addition to having to provide $15,000 in minimum gate receipts for the match, the Swedish Tennis Association was fined an additional $25,000. The [[Swedish Tennis Association]] responded by issuing penalties to Malmö mayor Ilmar Reepalu for his involvement in the event.{{Cite news|first=Federico|last=Moreno|title=Tennisförbundet skickar ny nota till Reepalu|url=http://www.sydsvenskan.se/malmo/tennisforbundet-skickar-ny-nota-till-reepalu/|work=Sydsvenskan|date=21 April 2010|language=Swedish}} The protest and riots led to accusations of [[antisemitism]] in Sweden.{{Cite news|title=Sverige anklagas för antisemitism|url=http://www.sydsvenskan.se/malmo/sverige-anklagas-for-antisemitism/|publisher=Sydsvenskan/TT|date=9 March 2009|language=Swedish}}{{Cite news|first=Anna|last=Ekström|title="Politiker måste agera mot antisemitism"|url=http://www.sydsvenskan.se/opinion/aktuella-fragor/politiker-maste-agera-mot-antisemitism/|publisher=Sydsvenskan|date=14 March 2009|language=Swedish}} Swedish history professor [[Kristian Gerner]] described the situation as "the worst crisis for Jews in Sweden since the Second World War." A 2012 European Men's Handball Championship [[2012 European Men's Handball Championship qualification#Group 4|qualifier between Sweden and Israel]] set to be played in [[Karlskrona]] in June 2011 raised concerns due to the riots, and was considered to be moved to another location by Swedish sports authorities.{{Cite news|title=Oro i Karlskrona för nya kravaller|url=http://www.aftonbladet.se/sportbladet/handboll/article12425388.ab|publisher=Aftonbladet/TT|language=Swedish}}{{Cite news|title=Politiker rädda för Israelkravaller|url=http://www.sydsvenskan.se/sport/handboll/politiker-radda-for-israelkravaller/|publisher=Sydsvenskan/TT|date=21 April 2010|language=Swedish}} The match was played as scheduled, with a minor anti-Israel demonstration being held.{{Cite news|title=Sweden-Israel Handball Game Sparks anti-Israel Protests|url=http://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/sweden-israel-handball-game-sparks-anti-israel-protests-1.367327|work=The Associated Press and Anna Ekström|publisher=Haaretz|date=13 June 2011}} ==See also== * [[Båstad riots]] * [[2008–09 Oslo riots]] * [[2008 Malmo riots]] * [[Malmö Synagogue#Attacks|2010 & 2012 Malmö synagogue arson attacks]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Malmo Davis Cup riots}} [[Category:2009 Davis Cup]] [[Category:2009 in Sweden]] [[Category:2009 riots]] [[Category:2009 in tennis]] [[Category:Riots and civil disorder in Sweden]] [[Category:Sports riots]] [[Category:Political riots]] [[Category:2009 crimes in Sweden]] [[Category:Gaza War (2008–09)]] [[Category:Antisemitic attacks and incidents]] [[Category:Anti-Zionism in Sweden]] [[Category:Islamism in Sweden]] [[Category:Nazism in Sweden]] [[Category:Left Party (Sweden)]] [[Category:Israel–Sweden relations]] [[Category:Politics and sports]] [[Category:March 2009 events in Europe]] [[Category:2000s in Malmö]] [[Category:Antisemitism in Sweden]] [[Category:2009 Davis Cup Europe/Africa Zone]]

{{For|AISTs or Aists|AIST (disambiguation){{!}}AIST}} {{Primary sources|date=April 2009}} {{Infobox Organization |name = International Academy of Sport Science and Technology |image = |size = 240px |motto = |type = Sports education and research |formation = 2000 |headquarters = [[Lausanne]], [[Switzerland]] |membership = 87 [[List of international sport federations|International Sports Federations]] |leader_title = Director |leader_name = [[Claude Stricker]] |language = [[English language|English]], [[French language|French]] |website= [http://aists.org aists.org] |}}
The '''International Academy of Sport Science and Technology''' (French: ''Académie internationale des sciences et techniques du sport'', '''AISTS''') is a non-profit foundation based in [[Lausanne, Switzerland]], the Olympic Capital. Each year the AISTS delivers over 900 hours of continuing education, workshops, seminars and projects to the sports industry. The AISTS is committed to professionalising sports management through continuing education, applied research and an engaging platform for industry connections and is ranked the number 1 sports management programme in the world (Eduniversal 2015/16).
==About AISTS== The International Academy of Sports Science and Technology is focused on [[sport management]] worldwide by offering sports management programs through sports management graduate programs, continuing professional education, and applied research in sport.
The AISTS mission is to apply knowledge to the study of sports, incorporating the disciplines of [[management]], [[economics]], [[technology]], [[medicine]], [[biology]], [[law]], [[logistics]], [[sociology]], and [[ethics]]. The AISTS supports sport innovation, [[technology transfer]] and [[business development]].
The academy’s activities are built upon three pillars: * [[Postgraduate education]] * [[Continuing education]] * [[Research]]
The main service offered by the academy is its Master of Advanced Studies in Sport Administration and Technology (MAS); a 15 month postgraduate master’s programme training sport executives.
In addition, continuing education seminars for sports management worldwide are organized under the lead of the academy including the “Sport Event Management and Organisation Seminar” (SEMOS), and the “Sustainable Sport and Events Open Module” (SSE). In addition the AISTS offers Risk Management Conferences on various topics including Security Risks at Sport Events and Sport Concussion for International Sport Governing Bodies.
The AISTS is incorporated as a foundation (Art 80ss, Swiss law), which forms a network of the following founding members: * [[International Olympic Committee]] * [[International Institute for Management Development]] (IMD) * [[Swiss Federal Institute of Technology in Lausanne|Swiss Federal Institute of Technology in Lausanne (EPFL)]] * [[University of Lausanne]] * [[University of Geneva]] * [[École hôtelière de Lausanne|Ecole hôtelière de Lausanne]] (EHL) * Canton of Vaud
==History== AISTS was founded in 2000 by the [[International Olympic Committee]] (IOC), the [[Swiss Federal Institute of Technology in Lausanne]] (EPFL), the [[International Institute for Management Development]], the [[University of Lausanne]], the [[University of Geneva]], the [[Swiss Graduate School of Public Administration|Swiss Graduate School of Public Administration (IDHEAP)]], the [[École hôtelière de Lausanne]] (EHL), the City of [[Lausanne]] and the [[Canton of Vaud]].
== Sports management programmes == AISTS has the support of the International Olympic Committee for sports management worldwide, and has strong links to the worldwide Olympic Movement.
===Sports management applied research=== AISTS delivers knowledge from [[human sciences]], [[life sciences]] and [[engineering]] [[sciences]]. AISTS acts as an advisor and manager to sporting and non-sporting organizations such as the International Olympic Committee, international sports federations (Ski, Volleyball, Basketball, etc.), and national sports federations.
===Sports management educational programmes=== AISTS provides sports management graduate programs by the Master of Advanced Studies in Sport Administration and Technology (MAS)
====Master of Advanced Studies in Sport Administration and Technology (MAS) ==== The AISTS MAS (Master of Advanced Studies) in Sports Administration and Technology is a sports management graduate program in sports management. Training is offered in Sports Management & Economics, Technology, Law, Sociology, and sports Medicine. A multidisciplinary master's degree co-signed by the [[Swiss Federal Institute of Technology in Lausanne]], the University of Geneva and the [[University of Lausanne]]. Every year, it attracts graduate students and professionals from all continents (85% of the students are not Swiss). '''MAS - [http://aists.org Master of Advanced Studies in Sports Administration and Technology]'''
===Sports management program seminars===
====Sustainable Sport and Event Open Module ==== Over two days, the Sustainable Sport & Events Learning Module provides an understanding of the current challenges and opportunities of sustainability in sport. This understanding will be reinforced through a number of case studies, which offer concrete examples of what leading sports organisations, such as FIFA, the International Olympic Committee and the International Automobile Federation are achieving in this area. Participants will also gain insight into the best practices adopted by the American major leagues such as the NFL, NBA and MLB. Throughout both days, group work and discussions will challenge the existing ideas of sustainability in sport, with a particular focus on the business case for sustainability while simultaneously addressing the demands of multiple stakeholders.
====SEMOS (Sport Event Management and Organisation Seminar)==== The AISTS SEMOS module offers an overview of the key tasks that sports managers need to successfully plan, communicate and operate when organising sport events, providing a 360° view and behind the scenes look at the mechanics of sport events. Bringing together leaders of International Sport Federations and other experts of the AISTS network, including the International Olympic Committee and sport event organisers, AISTS SEMOS is both pertinent and practical, and recognises the increased expectations of spectators, media and sponsors at major events.
==See also== * [[International Olympic Committee]] (IOC) * [[Sports management]] * [[Sports medicine]] * [[European Athletics]] * [[Union of European Football Associations]] (UEFA) * [[International Ski Federation]] (FIS) * [[Union Cycliste Internationale]] (UCI) * [[International Tennis Federation]] (ITF) * [[World Taekwondo Federation]] * [[International Basketball Federation]] (FIBA) * [[Athletissima]] * [[Canton of Vaud]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://aists.org Official website] * [http://aists.org/msa Master of Advanced Studies in Sport Administration & Technology (MAS)]
