== Explanations for participation and performance disparities ==
=== Physiological factors === A 1994 examination of 32 English sport/exercise science textbooks found that seven suggested that there are biophysical differences due to race that might explain differences in sports performance, one expressed caution with the idea, and the other 24 did not mention the issue.<ref>[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_hb6401/is_n1_v17/ai_n28638110/ "The presentation of human biological diversity in sport and exercise science textbooks: the example of "race.""], Christopher J. Hallinan, ''Journal of Sport Behavior'', March 1994</ref>
=== Socioeconomic factors === In ''Stuck in the Shallow End: Education, Race, and Computing'', [[UCLA]] researcher Jane Margolis outlines the history of segregation in swimming in the United States to show how blacks have been affected up to the present day by inadequate access to swimming facilities and [[Swimming lessons|lessons]].<ref name="Margolis">{{cite book |last1=Margolis |first1=Jane |authorlink1= |last2= |first2= |authorlink2= |editor1-first= |editor1-last= |editor1-link= |others= |title=Stuck in the Shallow End: Education, Race, and Computing |trans-title=|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WOI9rGJSFCcC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false |format= |accessdate=April 4, 2011 |type= |edition= |series= |volume= |year=2008 |origyear= |publisher=MIT Press Books |location= |language= |isbn=978-0-262-13504-7 |oclc= |doi= |id= |page= |pages=17–26 |at= |trans-chapter=|chapter=An Unlikely Metaphor: The Color Line in Swimming and Computer Science |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=WOI9rGJSFCcC&lpg=PP1&pg=PA17#v=onepage&q&f=false |quote= |ref= |bibcode= |laysummary= |laydate= |separator= |postscript= |lastauthoramp=}}</ref> Margolis asserts that physiological differences between ethnic groups are relatively minor and says: "In most cases of segregation, stereotypes and belief systems about different ethnic gender groups' genetic make-up and physical abilities (and inabilities) emerge to rationalize unequal access and resulting disparities."<ref name="Margolis" /> According to Margolis, views regarding "buoyancy problems" of [[African Americans]] are merely part of [[folklore]] which have been passed down from generation to generation.<ref name="Margolis" /> Joan Ferrante, a professor of sociology at [[Northern Kentucky University]], suggests that geographic location, financial resources, and the influence of parents, peers, and role models are involved in channeling individuals of certain races towards particular sports and away from others.<ref name="Ferrante">{{cite book |last1=Ferrante |first1=Joan |authorlink1=Joan Ferrante |last2= |first2= |authorlink2= |editor1-first= |editor1-last= |editor1-link= |others= |title=Seeing Sociology:An Introduction |trans-title=|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0vEbS8oBYSQC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false |format= |accessdate= |type= |edition= |series= |volume= |year=2011 |origyear= |publisher=Cengage Learning |location= |language= |isbn=978-0-495-60485-3 |oclc= |doi= |id= |page= |pages=284–285 |at= |trans-chapter=|chapter=Race and ethnicity: Flaws in Racist Arguments |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=0vEbS8oBYSQC&lpg=PP1&vq=sport&pg=PA284#v=onepage&q=sport&f=false |quote= |ref= |bibcode= |laysummary= |laydate= |separator= |postscript= |lastauthoramp=}}</ref>
=== Haplogroup inheritance === Elite athletic capacity has also been correlated with differing patterns of haplogroup inheritance. Moran et al. (2004) observed that among Y-DNA (paternal) clades borne by elite endurance athletes in Ethiopia, the [[Haplogroup E-P2|E*]], [[Haplogroup E-P2|E3*]], [[Haplogroup K (Y-DNA)|K*(xP)]],<ref name="Moran-a">{{cite journal|last1=Moran, Colin N., et al.|title=Y chromosome haplogroups of elite Ethiopian endurance runners|journal=Human Genetics|date=2004|volume=115|issue=6|page=495|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Colin_Moran/publication/8214295_Y_chromosome_haplogroups_of_elite_Ethiopian_endurance_runners/links/54b8e8800cf28faced625c07.pdf|accessdate=6 February 2017|doi=10.1007/s00439-004-1202-y}}</ref> and [[Haplogroup J (Y-DNA)|J*(xJ2)]]<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Moran, Colin N., et al.|title=Y chromosome haplogroups of elite Ethiopian endurance runners|journal=Human Genetics|date=2004|volume=115|issue=6|page=494 (Fig. 1)|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Colin_Moran/publication/8214295_Y_chromosome_haplogroups_of_elite_Ethiopian_endurance_runners/links/54b8e8800cf28faced625c07.pdf|accessdate=6 February 2017|doi=10.1007/s00439-004-1202-y}}</ref> are positively correlated with elite athletic endurance performance, whereas the haplogroup [[Haplogroup E-M215 (Y-DNA)|E3b1]] is significantly less frequent among the elite endurance athletes.<ref name="Moran-a"/>
Citing haplogroup data from various previous studies, Ahmetov and Fedotovskaya (2012) report that the [[Human mitochondrial DNA haplogroup|mtDNA]] (maternal) haplogroups [[Haplogroup I (mtDNA)|I]], [[Haplogroup H (mtDNA)|H]], [[Haplogroup L0 (mtDNA)|L0]], [[Haplogroup M (mtDNA)|M*]], [[Haplogroup G (mtDNA)|G1]], [[Haplogroup N (mtDNA)|N9]], and [[Haplogroup V (mtDNA)|V]] have been positively correlated with elite athletic endurance performance, whereas the mtDNA haplogroups [[Haplogroup L3 (mtDNA)|L3*]], [[Haplogroup B (mtDNA)|B]], [[Haplogroup K (mtDNA)|K]], [[Haplogroup J (mtDNA)|J2]], and [[Haplogroup T (mtDNA)|T]] are negatively correlated with athletic endurance performance. Japanese sprinters were also found to have a higher distribution of the mtDNA [[Haplogroup F (mtDNA)|F]].<ref name="Ahmetov">Ahmetov, Ildus I. and Olga N. Fedotovskaya (2012). Sports genomics: Current state of knowledge and future directions. In Cellular and Molecular Exercise Physiology Vol. 1, Issue 1.</ref>
== Racial prejudices, discrimination, segregation, and integration == {{Globalize/US|section|date=September 2016}} The [[baseball color line]], which included separate [[Negro league baseball]], was one example of [[racial segregation in the United States]].
In the United States, a study found that a form of racial discrimination exists in NBA basketball, as white players received higher salaries than do blacks related to actual performance. <!--When? How many? Criteria?--> Funk says this may be due to viewer discrimination. Viewership increases when there is greater participation by white players, which means higher advertising incomes. This explains much of the salary gap.<ref name=Funk2001>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1093/ei/39.4.599 | pmc = | pmid = | last1 = Kanazawa | first1 = M. T. | last2 = Funk | first2 = J. P. | title = Racial Discrimination in Professional Basketball: Evidence from Nielsen Ratings | journal = Economic Inquiry | volume = 39 | issue = 4 | pages = 599–608 | year = 2001 |url= http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_hb5814/is_4_39/ai_n28875951/}}</ref>
Researchers have looked at other evidence for sports consumer discrimination. One method is comparing the price of sports memorabilia, such as baseball cards. Another is looking at fan voting for all-star teams. Still another is looking at willingness to attend sporting events. The evidence is mixed, with some studies finding bias against blacks and others not. A bias, if it exists, may be diminishing and possibly disappearing, according to a study on fan voting for baseball all-star teams.<ref name=Funk2001 />
=== Major League Baseball === {{Main article|Baseball color line}}
Debuting with the [[History of the Brooklyn Dodgers|Brooklyn Dodgers]] in 1947, [[Jackie Robinson]] was the first [[African American|black]] [[Major League Baseball]] player of the modern era.
{| class="wikitable" |+Blacks in American baseball |- |Year |Major leagues |Population |Ratio |- |1945 |2% |10% |1:5 |- |1959 |17% |11% |3:2 |- |1975 |27% |11% |5:2 |- |1995 |19% |12% |3:2 |}<ref>[http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/sports/baseball/story/2012-04-15/baseball-jackie-robinson/54302108/1 USA Today]</ref><ref>[http://www.infoplease.com/ipa/A0922246.html Information Please Almanac]</ref>
The under-representation of blacks in U.S. baseball ended during the early years of the [[civil rights movement]]. The representation of different races in Major League Baseball has been increasing since 1947 according to Mark Armour and Daniel R Levitt of the Society for American Baseball Research. According to their research, African American representation reached its peak in 1984 when it reached 18.4%. However, the African American representation has been steadily decreasing since that point. As of 2016, the African American representation was down to 6.7%.
According to Armour and Levitt, the Latino representation has been steadily increasing since 1947. That year, the representation was only at 0.7%. Since that time, the Latino representation in baseball has increased substantially. As of 2016, the Latino representation was at 27.4%.
Asian American representation in baseball has been much less abundant throughout the game’s history according to Armour and Levitt. Their representation in the Major League did not get over 1% until 1999 when their representation was at 1.2%. While the representation is increasing, it is doing so significantly slower than the other races. As of 2016 Asian American representation was only at 2.1%, a small increase from 1999.
According to Armour and Levitt, Whites make up the largest portion of the different races represented in the Major League. However, their representation has been steadily declining as the African American, Asian, and Latino representation has been steadily on the rise. The Society for American Baseball research shows that white representation was at 98.3% in 1947. Since then, representation has decreased to 63.7% in 2016.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dettman|first=David|date=2017-03-20|title=SABR’s Guide to Doing Baseball ResearchRR 2017/084 SABR’s Guide to Doing Baseball Research Society for American Baseball Research (SABR) Phoenix, AZ 2012- URL: http://sabr.org/how-to Last visited October 2016 Gratis, with some content restricted to SABR members|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1108/rr-10-2016-0248|journal=Reference Reviews|volume=31|issue=3|pages=28–28|doi=10.1108/rr-10-2016-0248|issn=0950-4125}}</ref>
In a journal titled Using Giddens's Structuration Theory to Examine the Waning Participation of African Americans in Baseball, it says “Numerous studies have shown that African-American youths are more likely than Whites to be encouraged and even directed to play basketball over other sports."<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ogden|first=David|last2=Rose|first2=Randall A.|date=2005-03|title=Using Giddens’s Structuration Theory to Examine the Waning Participation of African Americans in Baseball|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1177/0021934704266091|journal=Journal of Black Studies|volume=35|issue=4|pages=225–245|doi=10.1177/0021934704266091|issn=0021-9347}}</ref>
=== National Basketball Association === {{Main article|National Basketball Association}} Although [[Japanese-American]] [[Wataru Misaka]] broke the [[National Basketball Association]]'s color barrier in the 1947–48 season when he played for the [[New York Knicks]], 1950 is recognized as the year the NBA integrated. That year [[African-American]] players joined several teams; they included [[Chuck Cooper (basketball)|Chuck Cooper]] with the [[Boston Celtics]], [[Nathaniel "Sweetwater" Clifton|Nat "Sweetwater" Clifton]] with the [[New York Knicks]], and [[Earl Lloyd]] with the [[Washington Bullets]].
=== National Football League === {{see also|Black players in American professional football|Racial issues faced by black quarterbacks}} Black players participated in the [[National Football League]] from its inception in 1920; however, there were no African-American players from 1933 to 1946. There is a great deal of speculation as to why this “gentleman’s agreement”, as it became to be called, was implemented during this era. Some argue that it was purely because of the Great Depression. Jobs were difficult to come by, and thus race relations became increasingly strained as African-Americans, and other minorities, became perceived as “threats”. Finally, in 1946, the Los Angeles Rams broke this unofficial “agreement” and drafted Kenny Washington along with Woody Strode in the same year. The final NFL team to break this agreement was the Washington Redskins, who signed Bobby Mitchell in 1962.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.4135/9781526438126|title=Media Industries and Sport Scandals: Deadspin, Sports Illustrated, ESPN, and the Manti Te’o Hoax|last=Burroughs|first=Benjamin|last2=Vogan|first2=Travis|date=2015|publisher=Human Kinetics, Inc.|isbn=9781526438126|location=1 Oliver's Yard, 55 City Road, London EC1Y 1SP United Kingdom}}</ref>
In October 2018, George Taliaferro, the first African American who played in NFL died at the age of 91.<ref>[https://eu.usatoday.com/story/sports/2018/10/08/indiana-nfl-star-george-taliaferro-dies/1574290002/ George Taliaferro, first African-American ever taken in NFL draft, dies at 91]</ref> While George was the first African American drafted to play in the NFL, the first African American would not be drafted as the Quarterback until 1953, when Willie Thrower was drafted to play with the Chicago Bears.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=1993-09-01|title=Professional football: the official Pro Football Hall of Fame bibliography|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.5860/choice.31-0054|journal=Choice Reviews Online|volume=31|issue=01|pages=31–0054-31-0054|doi=10.5860/choice.31-0054|issn=0009-4978}}</ref> It wouldn’t be for another 14 years, 1967, until the first African American, Emlen Tunnell, would be elected for the NFL Hall of Fame.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=1993-09-01|title=Professional football: the official Pro Football Hall of Fame bibliography|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.5860/choice.31-0054|journal=Choice Reviews Online|volume=31|issue=01|pages=31–0054-31-0054|doi=10.5860/choice.31-0054|issn=0009-4978}}</ref>
=== Professional Golfers Association === In 1961, the "Caucasians only" clause was struck from the [[Professional Golfers' Association of America]] constitution.
Throughout the game’s history, golf has not included many African-American players.They were often denied the opportunity to golf. However, many found a way to play the game anyway. According to an article by the African-American Registry titled African-Americans and Golf, a Brief History, “the Professional Golf Association of America (PGA) fought hard and until 1961, successfully maintained its all-white status. Black golfers (then) created their own organization of touring professionals.”<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/422755031|title=African American history : an introduction|last=1945-|first=Turner-Sadler, Joanne,|date=2009|publisher=Peter Lang|isbn=9781433107436|edition=Rev. ed|location=New York|oclc=422755031}}</ref>
Tiger Woods has had a major impact on the game of golf, especially among minorities. The article, African-Americans and Golf, a Brief History, states “With the assent of Tiger Woods and his golf game comes an increased interest and participation from young minorities in the game. He himself envisions this impacting in the next ten years as they come of age and develop physically as well." Woods hopes minority participation will continue to increase in the future.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/422755031|title=African American history : an introduction|last=1945-|first=Turner-Sadler, Joanne,|date=2009|publisher=Peter Lang|isbn=9781433107436|edition=Rev. ed|location=New York|oclc=422755031}}</ref>
African American participation in golf has been increasing. In a journal titled African American Culture and Physical Skill Development Programs: The Effect on Golf after Tiger Woods, it says “Smith (1997) reported data from a National Golf Foundation (NDF) study in the United States indicating there are 676,000 African-American golfers (27% of the 24.7 million golfers)."<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Roberson|first=Venita|date=2003-07|title=African American Culture and Physical Skill Development Programs|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1177/0021934703033006005|journal=Journal of Black Studies|volume=33|issue=6|pages=801–816|doi=10.1177/0021934703033006005|issn=0021-9347}}</ref>
As African-American participation increased, Asian participation in professional golf has also increased. According to an article by Golfweek titled Record Number of Asian Golfers Compete for Masters Glory, there were 10 golfers which was a tournament record. <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Romine|first=Brentley|last2=|first2=|last3=|first3=|last4=|first4=|date=April 2018|title=Record Number of Asian Golfers Compete for Masters Glory|url=golfweek.com/2018/04/05/record-number-of-asian-golfers-compete-formasters -glory/.|journal=Golfweek|volume=|issue=|pages=|doi=|issn=|via=}}</ref>
According to the article Where are all the black golfers? Nearly two decades after Tiger Woods’ arrival, golf still struggles to attract minorities, As of 2013 there were 25.7 million golfers which are composed of 20.3 million whites, 3.1 million Hispanics, 1.3 million African-Americans, and 1 million Asian-Americans. The lack of diversity is still very apparent in golf today.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bamberger|first=Michael|last2=|first2=|last3=|first3=|last4=|first4=|date=July 2013|title=Where Are All the Black Golfers? Nearly Two Decades after Tiger Woods' Arrival, Golf Still Struggles to Attract Minorities.”|url=Golf.com, 3 July 2013, www.golf.com/tour-and-news/where-are-all-black-golfers-nearly-two-decades-after -tiger-wOods-arrival-golf-still-st.|journal=golf|volume=|issue=|pages=|doi=|issn=|via=}}</ref>
=== Positions of power: coaching and administration === Referring to quarterbacks, head coaches, and athletic directors, [[Kenneth L. Shropshire]] of the [[Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania]] has described the number of African Americans in "positions of power" as "woefully low".<ref name=autogenerated3 /> In 2000, 78% of players in the NBA were black, but only 33% of NBA officials were minorities.<ref name=autogenerated5>Duncan 2009, p. 200.</ref> The lack of minorities in positions of leadership has been attributed to racial stereotypes as well "[[old boy network]]s" and white administrators [[business networking|networking]] within their own race.<ref name=autogenerated5 /> In 2003, the NFL implemented the [[Rooney Rule]], requiring teams searching for a new [[head coach]] to interview at least one minority candidate.<ref name=autogenerated5 />
Similar to the discrepancy between participation and leadership of blacks in American professional sports leagues, NCAA sports also have had a low percentage of administrators and coaches relative to the number of athletes. For example, during the 2005–2006 academic year, high revenue NCAA sports (basketball and football) had 51 percent black student athletes, whereas only 17 percent of head coaches in the same high revenue sports were black<ref>{{cite book|last=Hawkins|first=Billy|title=The New Plantation: Black Athletes, College Sports, and Predominantly White NCAA Institutions|year=2010|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|location=New York|pages=141–42}}</ref> Also, in the same 2005–2006 year, only 5.5 percent of athletic directors at Division I "PWIs" (Primarily White Institutions), were black.<ref name="Hawkins 2010 141">{{cite book|last=Hawkins|first=Billy|title=The New Plantation: Black Athletes, College Sports, and Predominantly White NCAA Institutions|year=2010|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|location=New York|pages=141}}</ref> Terry Bowden, a notable white Division I football coach, suggests that the reason many university presidents will not hire black coaches is "because they are worried about how alumni and donors will react."<ref name="Hawkins 2010 141" /> Bowden also refers to the "untapped talent"<ref name="Hawkins 2010" /> existing within the ranks of assistant coaches in Division I football. The data backs up this claim, with 26.9 percent of Division I assistant coaches during the 2005-06 year in men's revenue sports being black,<ref>{{cite book|last=Hawkins|first=Billy|title=The New Plantation: Black Athletes, College Sports, and Predominantly White NCAA Institutions|year=2010|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|location=New York|pages=142}}</ref> a notably higher percentage than of head coaches. In terms of administrative positions, they have been concentrated largely in the hands of whites. As recently as 2009, 92.5 percent of university presidents in the FBS were white, 87.5 percent of athletic directors were white, and 100 percent of the conference commissioners were white.<ref>{{cite web|last=Scott|first=Kevin|title=Tennessee's Hire Shows Racism is Alive and Well in College Football|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/326890-tennessee-vols-hiring-of-dooley-shows-racism-in-cf-alive-and-well}}</ref> Despite these statistics, black head coaches have become more prevalent at the FBS level. As of 2012, there are now 15 black head coaches in FBS football,<ref>{{cite web|last=Miller|first=Ted|title=Opportunities for black coaches on the rise|url=http://espn.go.com/college-football/story/_/id/7623932/opportunities-black-coaches-rise-college-football}}</ref> including now 3 in the SEC, a conference that did not hire its first black head coach until 2003.<ref>{{cite news|last=Habib|first=Daniel G.|title=The Road Ahead: Sylvester Croom's arrival at Mississippi State just starts another journey|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1030815/index.htm|work=CNN|date=15 December 2003}}</ref>
=== Segregated seating === In 1960, the [[Houston Oilers]] implemented a policy at [[Jeppesen Stadium]] to [[Racial segregation in the United States|segregate]] the black fans from the white fans.<ref>Lomax 2008, p. xii.</ref> [[Clem Daniels]], [[Art Powell (wide receiver)|Art Powell]], [[Bo Roberson]], and [[Fred Williamson]] of the [[Oakland Raiders]] refused to play in a stadium that had segregated seating. The 1963 game against the [[New York Jets]] was relocated to a different stadium.<ref>Lomax 2008, p. xiv.</ref>
=== Mascot controversies === {{Main article|Native American mascot controversy}} The use of [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native American]] names and imagery for [[mascot|sport mascots]] or in franchise memorabilia is an issue of ongoing discussion and controversy in American sports, as some Native American representatives have objected to such use without explicit negotiation and permission.<ref>Duncan 2009, p. 202.</ref>
=== Promoting racial harmony and breaking stereotypes === According to William Jeynes, a professor of education at [[California State University, Long Beach]], the gathering at the [[Thanksgiving (United States)|first Thanksgiving in the United States]] was an attempt to create racial harmony through games and sporting contests that included [[running]], [[shooting]] and [[wrestling]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Jeynes |first1=William |authorlink1= |last2= |first2= |authorlink2= |editor1-first= |editor1-last= |editor1-link= |others= |title=American Educational History: School, Society, and the Common Good |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FL2WYw0ve-0C&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false |format= |accessdate=April 13, 2011 |type= |edition= |series= |volume= |year=2007 |origyear= |publisher=Sage Publications |location= |language= |isbn=978-1-4129-1421-5 |oclc= |doi= |id= |page=9 |pages= |at= |trans-chapter=|chapter=The Colonial Experience, 1607–1776: Puritans' and Pilgrims' Relationship with Native Americans |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=FL2WYw0ve-0C&lpg=PP1&pg=PA9#v=onepage&q&f=false |quote= |ref= |bibcode= |laysummary= |laydate= |separator= |postscript= |lastauthoramp=}}</ref> [[Huping Ling]], a professor of history at [[Truman State University]], has asserted that the participation of Chinese students in sports helped break local stereotypes in the St. Louis area during the 1920s.<ref>{{cite book |last1=LING |first1=Huping |authorlink1=Huping Ling |last2= |first2= |authorlink2= |editor1-first= |editor1-last= |editor1-link= |others= |title=Chinese St. Louis: From Enclave to Cultural Community |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=d48Fos9tv58C&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false |format= |accessdate= |type= |edition= |series= |volume= |year=2004 |origyear= |publisher=Temple University Press |location= |language= |isbn=978-1-59213-039-9 |oclc= |doi= |id= |page=112 |pages= |at= |trans-chapter=|chapter=Dwindling "Hop Alley"; 1920s – 1966 |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=d48Fos9tv58C&lpg=PP1&pg=PA112#v=onepage&q&f=false |quote= |ref= |bibcode= |laysummary= |laydate= |separator= |postscript= |lastauthoramp=}}</ref>This history of racial tension in the competition between whites and minority groups shows an attempt to prove the humanity, equality, and even occasionally their superiority on the playing field. By doing so, groups of minorities hoped that sports would serve as a source for racial pride that would eventually lead to upward social mobility. However, as early as 1984, criticism has been levied against these ideas. Sports sociologist Harry Edwards openly criticized African Americans as being “co-conspirators” in their own children’s exploitation by the white dominated sports establishment. Despite the the perception of a white dominated sports establishment, research has shown that there is greater emphasis on sports as a potential career path in the African American community compared to the White community. <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Beamon|first=Krystal K.|date=2009-08-27|title=Are Sports Overemphasized in the Socialization Process of African American Males? A Qualitative Analysis of Former Collegiate Athletes’ Perception of Sport Socialization|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1177/0021934709340873|journal=Journal of Black Studies|volume=41|issue=2|pages=281–300|doi=10.1177/0021934709340873|issn=0021-9347}}</ref>Edwards continued by arguing that placing so much emphasis on sports achievement as a way for minority groups, specifically referring to African Americans, to achieve some level of prominence is de-emphasizing the importance of intellectual pursuits.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Brooks|first=Scott N.|last2=Blackman|first2=Dexter|date=2011-10|title=INTRODUCTION: AFRICAN AMERICANS AND THE HISTORY OF SPORT—NEW PERSPECTIVES|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.5323/jafriamerhist.96.4.0441|journal=The Journal of African American History|volume=96|issue=4|pages=441–447|doi=10.5323/jafriamerhist.96.4.0441|issn=1548-1867}}</ref> Despite the conflicting perceptions of sports as a harmonizing instrument, many researchers still believe that not much has changed to alleviate the racially tense landscape many believe to be inherent in current day society. <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Miller|first=Patrick B.|date=1995|title=To "Bring the Race along Rapidly": Sport, Student Culture, and Educational Mission at Historically Black Colleges during the Interwar Years|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.2307/369629|journal=History of Education Quarterly|volume=35|issue=2|pages=111|doi=10.2307/369629|issn=0018-2680}}</ref>
== Issues in Sports Commentating == Racial remarks have been made about athletes of color throughout history. Radio host Don Imus described the Rutgers University women's basketball team as "nappy-headed hos" on his radio program "Inmus in the Morning" in 2007. Later on he proclaimed that the match-up between Rutgers and their opponents looked like a showdown of the "jigaboos versus the wannabes." <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://web.b.ebscohost.com/ehost/pdfviewer/pdfviewer?vid=1&sid=700de70c-5ec6-40f7-bd39-0874026cc1f4@pdc-v-sessmgr01|title=EBSCO Publishing Service Selection Page|website=web.b.ebscohost.com|access-date=2018-03-23}}</ref>
In 1988 sports commentator Jimmy "the Greek" Snyder proclaimed his theory on why Black Americans are more athletic than White Americans:
"The black is a better athlete to begin with because he's been bred to be that way, because of his high thighs and big thighs that goes up into his back, and they can jump higher and run faster because of their bigger thighs and he's bred to be the better athlete because this goes back all the way to the Civil War when during the slave trade … the slave owner would breed his big black to his big woman so that he could have a big black kid …"
Snyder was later fired by CBS. <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://web.b.ebscohost.com/ehost/pdfviewer/pdfviewer?vid=1&sid=642a95b8-81fc-494a-9afb-78131b9bc861@sessionmgr102|title=EBSCO Publishing Service Selection Page|website=web.b.ebscohost.com|access-date=2018-03-23}}</ref>
== People of Color in Commentating == Sherman Maxwell was the first African American sports broadcaster. He began his career in 1929 on WNJ radio. He was known as "the voice of Newark". <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ic.galegroup.com/ic/ovic/NewsDetailsPage/NewsDetailsWindow?disableHighlighting=&displayGroupName=News&docIndex=&source=&prodId=&mode=view&limiter=&display-query=&contentModules=&action=e&sortBy=&windowstate=normal&currPage=&dviSelectedPage=&scanId=&query=&search_within_results=&p=OVIC&catId=&u=csubak&displayGroups=&documentId=GALE%7CA181561747&activityType=&failOverType=&commentary=|title=Gale - Enter Product Login|website=ic.galegroup.com|access-date=2018-03-23}}</ref>
== Portrayals in film == The US-set films ''[[Hoosiers (film)|Hoosiers]]'' and ''[[Rudy (film)|Rudy]]'' have been described as memorializing the "golden age of sports" as a time of white prevalence and dominance,<ref>King 2006, p.189</ref> while ''[[Glory Road (film)|Glory Road]]'' showed [[Don Haskins|a white coach]] [[1965–66 Texas Western Miners basketball team|helping to dissolve]] the color barrier in college basketball.
''[[Invictus (film)|Invictus]]'' deals with the subject of the [[Rugby World Cup]] in post-apartheid South Africa.
== Australia == {{Main article|List of Indigenous Australian sportspeople}}
Inequality in sport for the [[Aboriginal Australian]]s exists due to material barriers.<ref>Giulianotti 2005, p.69-70.</ref> A 2007 report by the [[Australian Human Rights Commission]] suggested that fear of "racial vilification" was partly responsible for the under-representation of Aboriginal and other ethnic groups in Australian sports.<ref>http://www.foxsports.com.au/breaking-news/racism-common-in-australian-sport/story-e6frf33c-1111114656872#.UNn95bYj7cs</ref>
== South Africa == In [[South Africa]], black representation on the cricket and rugby [[national sports team]]s is ensured via the introduction of quotas.<ref>Giulianotti 2005, p.69.</ref>
== United States == Discussions of race and sports in the United States, where the two subjects have always been intertwined in [[American history]], have focused to a great extent on African Americans.<ref name=autogenerated1>Gems 2009, p. 238.</ref> Depending on the type of sport and performance level, African Americans are reported to be over- or under-represented.<ref name=autogenerated1 /> African Americans compose the highest percentage of the minority groups active at the professional level, but are among those who show the lowest participation overall.<ref name=autogenerated1 />
In 2013, while 2.8% of full-time degree-pursuing undergraduates were black men, the group comprised 57% of college football teams,<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://time.com/4110443/college-football-race-problem/ |title=College Football big problem with race |accessdate=November 13, 2016 |author=Diane Roberts |date=November 12, 2015 |publisher=Time magazine}}</ref> and 64% of men's basketball players.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/posteverything/wp/2015/11/11/black-college-football-and-basketball-players-are-the-most-powerful-people-of-color-on-campus/ |title=Black college football and basketball players are the most powerful people of color on campus |accessdate=November 13, 2016 |author=Shaun R. Harper |date=November 11, 2015 |publisher=Washington Post}}</ref> While blacks predominate in football and basketball, whites predominate in all other regulated sports.<ref name=smith/>
A 2001 study indicated that black high school students play harder than white students, because the former were more likely to perceive sports as a venue to success. The study denies that racial characteristics, per se, is a factor in success in sports.<ref name=smith>{{Cite web |url=http://www.science.smith.edu/exer_sci/ESS200/Raceh/Raceh.htm |title=Race and sport |accessdate=November 13, 2016|publisher=Smith College}}</ref>
For all races and sports, from 3.3% (basketball) to 11.3% (ice hockey) are successful in making the transition from high school varsity to an NCAA team.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.ncaa.org/about/resources/research/probability-competing-beyond-high-school |title=Probability of Competing Beyond High School |accessdate=November 13, 2016 |publisher=NCAA}}</ref> From .8% (men's ice hockey) to 9.4% (baseball) successfully transition from NCAA to professional teams. Therefore, the overall success rate of high school athletes progressing to professional athletes was from .03% (men and women's basketball) to .5% (baseball).<!---presume that baseball includes AAA minor leagues--> The annual number of NCAA athletes drafted into professional sports annually varied from seven (men's ice hockey) to 678 (baseball).<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.ncaa.org/about/resources/research/estimated-probability-competing-professional-athletics |title=Estimated probability of competing in professional athletics |accessdate=November 13, 2016 |publisher=NCAA }}</ref>
Unlike black athletes, blacks as a group have not perceived sports as an important venue to prosperity. There are higher participation rates by blacks as well as higher numbers of people in non-athletic endeavor, such as policy, teaching, physicians, lawyers, engineers, and architects.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.theroot.com/articles/history/2014/09/why_are_there_so_many_black_athletes/ |title=Why Are There So Many Black Athletes? |accessdate=November 13, 2016 |author=Henry Louis Gates Jr. |date=September 1, 2014 |publisher=theroot.com }}</ref>
Athletics have been increasingly subsidized by tuition. Only one in eight of the 202 [[NCAA Division I|Division I]] colleges actually netted more money than they spent on athletics between the years 2005 and 2010. At the few money making schools, [[American football|football]] and sometimes basketball sales support the school's other athletic programs. The amount spent on an athlete in one of the six highest-profile football conferences, on average, is six times more than the amount spent to educate the non-athlete. Spending per student varied from $10,012 to $19,225; cost per athlete varied from $41,796 to $163,931.<ref>{{Cite news | first=Mary Beth | last=Marklein | title=Athletics get more dollars than academics | url=http://www.floridatoday.com/usatoday/article/1837721| work= | newspaper=[[Florida Today]] | location=[[Melbourne, Florida]] | pages= 4A | date=January 16, 2013 | id= | accessdate=}}</ref><!---soft copy is missing "box" (present in hard copy) which has exact figures but otherwise supports this material--->

'''Side stitch''' (also called a '''side ache''', a '''side cramp''', a '''side crampie''', a '''side sticker''' or simply the '''stitch''') is an intense stabbing [[pain]] under the lower edge of the [[ribcage]] that occurs while [[exercise|exercising]]. It is also referred to as '''exercise-related transient abdominal pain''' ('''ETAP''').<ref name=pub_med_ischemia>{{cite journal|last=Morton|first=DP|author2=Callister, R |title=Characteristics and etiology of exercise-related transient abdominal pain.|journal=Medicine & Science in Sports & Exercise|date=February 2000|volume=32|issue=2|pages=432–438|pmid=10694128|doi=10.1097/00005768-200002000-00026}}</ref> Some people think that this [[abdominal pain]] may be caused by the internal organs (like the [[liver]] and [[stomach]]) pulling downwards on the [[Diaphragm (anatomy)|diaphragm]],<ref name=Collins09>{{cite book|last1=Collins|first1=Andrew|title=On Running on Lessons from 40 Years of Running.|date=2009|publisher=Authorhouse|location=Bloomington, IN|isbn=9781438936246|page=148|url=https://books.google.de/books?id=xovMmC_USRYC&pg=PA148|accessdate=12 October 2015}}</ref> but that theory is inconsistent with its frequent occurrence during [[Swimming (sport)|swimming]],<ref>"965 athletes in six different sports (running, swimming, cycling, aerobics, basketball, and horse riding). Over the course of a year of training and competition, 75% of swimmers had trouble with stitches, 69% of runners were afflicted, 62% of horse riders had ETAP, 52% of aerobics participants suffered, 47% of basketball players did so, and 32% of cyclists were affected " Characteristics and Etiology of Exercise-Related Transient Abdominal Pain,' Medicine & Science in Sports & Exercise, Volume 32 (2), pp. 432-438, 2000</ref> which involves almost no downward force on these organs. If the pain is present only when exercising and is completely absent at rest, in an otherwise healthy person, it does not require investigation.
== Causes == There is no single precise known reason for a stitch to occur. There are, however, a number of popular theories as to what may cause, increase the chances of, or otherwise exacerbate a stitch. A leading theory is that the pain may be caused by an increase in blood flow to the [[liver]] or [[spleen]]. Increases in the heart rate during exercise will force extra red blood cells into the liver which can cause temporary [[hepatomegaly]] and [[portal hypertension]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Clinically Oriented Anatomy|last=Moore|first=Keith|publisher=Lippincott Williams & Wilkins|year=1999|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> Temporary hepatomegaly and portal hypertension can restrict blood flow through the portal vein of the liver thus slowing blood flow to the rest of the body; this is why most runner's cramps are felt on the right side near the liver.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Muir|first=Brad|date=2009-12-01|title=Exercise related transient abdominal pain: a case report and review of the literature|journal=The Journal of the Canadian Chiropractic Association|volume=53|issue=4|pages=251–260|issn=0008-3194|pmc=2796944|pmid=20037690}}</ref> A plausible mechanism for the pain is that high internal pressure in the liver or spleen restricts blood flow, causing hypoxia.
There are other theories regarding side stitches than simple stretching of the [[viscus|visceral]] [[ligaments]] due to repeated vertical translation and jolting. Such theories include diaphragmatic [[ischemia]],<ref name="pub_med_ischemia" /><ref name="bbc">{{cite web|title=Having a stitch explained|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sportacademy/hi/sa/treatment_room/newsid_2131000/2131547.stm|publisher=BBC|accessdate=7 August 2013}}</ref> imbalances of the [[Thoracic vertebrae|thoracic spine]],<ref name="pub_med_posture">{{cite journal|last=Morton|first=DP|author2=Callister, R |title=Influence of posture and body type on the experience of exercise-related transient abdominal pain.|journal=Journal of science and medicine in sport / Sports Medicine Australia|date=September 2010|volume=13|issue=5|pages=485–8|pmid=20022301|doi=10.1016/j.jsams.2009.10.487}}</ref> irritation of the parietal [[peritoneum]]<ref name="pub_med_ischemia" /> and strain on visceral ligaments by a fluid-engorged gut.<ref name="pub_med_ischemia" /><ref name="bbc" /><ref name="pub_med_ligaments">{{cite journal|last=Plunkett|first=BT|author2=Hopkins, WG |title=Investigation of the side pain "stitch" induced by running after fluid ingestion.|journal=Medicine & Science in Sports & Exercise|date=August 1999|volume=31|issue=8|pages=1169–75|pmid=10449020|doi=10.1097/00005768-199908000-00014}}</ref>
A further theory points to shallow breathing as a possible cause for a stitch<ref name="webmd">{{cite web|title=How to Stop Runners' Cramps|url=http://www.webmd.com/fitness-exercise/features/how-to-stop-runners-cramps|publisher=WebMD|accessdate=7 August 2013}}</ref> and one possible preventative measure involves adjusting at what point in a runner's stride they inhale, or reducing the frequency of inhales (with an increase in inspiratory capacity).<ref name="ReferenceA">p 391 The Lore of Running, Tim Noakes, Publisher: Human Kinetics Publishers Date Published: 1991 {{ISBN|978-0-88011-438-7}} {{ISBN|0-88011-438-X}}</ref>
The reasons for the variety of theories include, in particular, the prevalence of ETAP during swimming.
Most of the time, side stitches occur on the right side of the body.<ref name=":0" /> This may be because the largest organ in the abdominal cavity, the liver, is on that side. Certain athletes also report a pain in the tip of their [[shoulder blade]]. This is believed to be because this is a [[Referred pain|referred site]] of pain for the diaphragm via the phrenic nerve.<ref name=pub_med_ischemia />{{better source|date=August 2013}} When the side stitch is on the right side, published advice is to try to exhale when the left foot lands.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
There is also a belief that an imbalance of electrolytes (such as calcium, potassium, and sodium) in the blood could also contribute to the side stitch.<ref name=webmd />
==See also== *[[Precordial catch syndrome]]

The effect of exercise on normal splenic volume measured with SPECT. Otto et al. *J Appl Physiol 74: 1024-1026,1993; Spleen emptying and venous hematocrit in humans during exercise. Laub et al.

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} [[File:Britney Europe.jpg|thumb|Rise in popularity of thongs among younger girls has been attributed to pop idols like [[Britney Spears]] and [[Jennifer Lopez]].<ref name="auto">[http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/chronicle/archive/2002/06/16/LV184497.DTL Grin and bare it], San Francisco Chronicles</ref> Picture shows Britney Spears performing, 2011.]] The '''social impact of thong underwear''' has been covered extensively in the media, ranging from a ban on wearing [[thong (clothing)|thong]]s to thongs for the underaged. The rise of thong usage has been asserted by Christian minister Oneil McQuick to be linked to a rise of [[sexualization]] in society,<ref>{{cite book|first=Oneil|last=McQuick|url=https://books.google.com/?id=Ewm93pO7YQcC&pg=PT1&dq=thong+society+sex|title=The Sexuality Series|page=29|publisher=L.I.M Publishing|year=2007|isbn=1-4196-4225-1}}</ref> and by Christian writer Philo Thelos to be linked to a rise in a desire to go unclothed.<ref>{{cite book|first=Philo|last=Thelos|url=https://books.google.com/?id=KpYJYeKiss8C&pg=PA52&dq=thong+society+sex|title=Divine Sex: Liberating Sex from Religious Tradition|page=52|publisher=Trafford Publishing|year=2003|isbn=1-55395-400-9}}</ref>
== Overview == [[File:Thong (cropped).jpg|thumb|Woman wearing a T-back thong in [[Sunrise, Florida]], USA in 2006]]
When discussing the trend of wearing thongs, Christian writer Sharon Daugherty comments in her book ''What Guys See That Girls Don't: Or Do They?'' that the fashion industry "may have changed the mindset of our society",<ref>{{cite book|first=Sharon|last=Daugherty|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g3kx5Z42GPYC||title=What Guys See That Girls Don't: Or Do They?|page=61|publisher=Destiny Image Publishers|year=2006|isbn=0-7684-2368-6}}</ref> which was followed by the observation that "the whole idea of wearing so that no panty line or bumps can show isn't substantiated" and that "the thong was created by fashion designers to arouse sexual thoughts".{{sfn|Daugherty|2006|page=63}}
[[Monica Lewinsky]] gave evidence during the [[Lewinsky scandal]] that she was flirting with [[Bill Clinton]] in [[Leon Panetta]]'s office, and that she lifted her jacket to show him the straps of her thong underwear above her pants.<ref>{{cite web | last = Starr | first = Kenneth | author-link = Ken Starr | title = Report to the House on President Clinton: Narrative Pt. II: Initial Sexual Encounters (extract) | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/politics/special/clinton/icreport/6narritii.htm | website = washingtonpost.com | publisher = [[The Washington Post]] | date = September 1998 }}</ref> Some of the news media in America used thong underwear as a metonym for smut in the [[Starr Report]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/explainer/1998/09/the_thong_show.html|title=The Thong Show|date=22 September 1998|publisher=|via=Slate}}</ref> According to feminist commentator [[Carrie Lukas]], Lewinsky "with her thong-snapping seduction, forever changed the image of the D.C. junior staffer from aspiring policy wonk to sexual temptress."<ref>{{citation | last = Lukas | first = Carrie | author-link = Carrie Lukas | contribution = Sex: love's got something to do with it | editor-last = Lukas | editor-first = Carrie | editor-link = Carrie Lukas | title = The politically incorrect guide to women, sex, and feminism | page = 21 | publisher = Regency Publishing | location = Washington, DC Lanham, Maryland | year = 2006 | isbn = 9781596980037 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=BVf_dCr023IC&pg=PA21&dq=thong+woman+sex&lr=&ei=sw4FSOahHIT6yATl3pj-Dw&sig=OCS8-3Pm9Npbe4q3ZRklqehUVzE#PPA21,M1 Preview.]</ref>
Marketing analysts Marian L. Salzman, Ira Matathia and Ann O'Reilly observed in the book ''Buzz: Harness the Power of Influence and Create Demand'' that thong brands are riding on the wide media coverage of thongs to create [[Word of mouth|buzz]].<ref>Marian L. Salzman, Ira Matathia and Ann O'Reilly, [https://books.google.com/books?id=sf85DYe9140C&pg=PA116&dq=thong+society+sex&lr=&ei=4vcESNDMF5jWyATNt_D9Dg&sig=f7ebSu-0y8UlAac7H8tqhsOIUiw Buzz: Harness the Power of Influence and Create Demand], Page 116, John Wiley and Sons, 2003, {{ISBN|0-471-27345-7}}</ref> Photographer [[Lauren Greenfield]] wrote in her book ''Girl Culture'', "Understanding the [[dialectic]] between the extreme and the mainstream – the anorexic and the dieter, the stripper and the teenager who bares her midriff or wears a thong – is essential to understanding contemporary feminine identity."<ref>Lauren Greenfield, [https://books.google.com/books?id=TUT9vKPr4_YC&pg=PT155&dq=thong+britney+spears&lr=&ei=TxEFSNTxLYOOywSSjuCiDw&sig=gCRLKGJiBIpHS_FdG9K02x9uk4k Girl Culture], Chronicle Books, 2002, {{ISBN|0-8118-3790-4}}</ref>
In 2004, political commentator Cedric Muhammad wrote in essay ''The Thong versus the Veil'', "We wondered at the end of the day, of the two groups of women most prominently featured on American TV these days, who gains more respect for their intellect and spirit – the Afghan woman who is so totally veiled that you can't even see her eyes or the Black woman in the R&B and Hip-Hop video who dances while wearing a bikini and thong?"<ref>Laura Flanders (ed.), [https://books.google.com/books?id=gg5NNztsUooC&pg=PA180&dq=thong+culutre+sex&lr=&ei=DhgFSLXXPJTAzATBy_yXDg&sig=QZNRmkA0_poI66Hywqj9tkkPYyg#PPA181,M1 The W Effect: Bush's War on Women], Page 181, Feminist Press, 2004, {{ISBN|1-55861-471-0}}</ref>
==School restrictions== The dress code for [[St. Ambrose Academy]], a Roman Catholic middle school and high school in [[Madison, Wisconsin]], specifically addresses swimsuits with "thong-cut legs" as inappropriate.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ambroseacademy.org/dresscode.pdf |title=Ambrose Academy website |publisher=Ambroseacademy.org |accessdate=1 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080727005219/http://www.ambroseacademy.org/dresscode.pdf |archivedate=27 July 2008 |df=dmy }}</ref> At [[Dixon High School (California)|Dixon High School]] in [[Dixon, California]], the dress code specifies that all undergarments – specifically listing thongs, along with [[bra]]s and [[briefs]] – must be covered.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dhs.dixonusd.org/PAGES/Information/rules_dress.htm |title=Dixon High School |publisher=Dhs.dixonusd.org |date= |accessdate=2013-03-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011210154/http://dhs.dixonusd.org/PAGES/Information/rules_dress.htm |archivedate=11 October 2007 |df=dmy }}</ref> [[University of Victoria]] Law School briefly put the school logo on thongs, but quickly pulled them from sale after controversy sprung up.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indissent.com/jan2003/lawnews.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030810135944/http://www.indissent.com/jan2003/lawnews.htm |archivedate=2003-08-10 |title=Indissent, University of Victoria |publisher=Web.archive.org |date=10 August 2003 |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref>
In 1999 a [[Miami University]] male professor was banned from using the school's recreation center because he refused to stop wearing thong swimwear. The professor challenged the school in court.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://enquirer.com/editions/1999/03/02/loc_professor_sues_miami.html|title= Professor sues Miami U to keep thong swimsuit |date=2 March 1999|accessdate=6 January 2016|publisher=[[Cincinnati Enquirer]]}}</ref> In 2000 a [[Salinas, California|Salinas]] High School principal was in the center of a variety of controversies including bans on clothing to the extent that "thong panties were unofficially banned." One student alleged that she was given a dress-code violation note for wearing a thong.<ref name="Monterey County Weekly" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metroactive.com/papers/metro/12.14.00/dresscode-0050.html |title=Metro Active |publisher=Metro Active |date=14 September 2000 |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref> This story made national headlines in the United States.<ref name="Monterey County Weekly">[https://archive.is/20070628153120/http://www.montereycountyweekly.com/articles/7128/print Monterey County Weekly] </ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0009/13/tod.04.html |title=CNN transcript |publisher=Transcripts.cnn.com |date=13 September 2000 |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref>
In 2002, a female high school vice principal in San Diego physically checked up to 100 female students' underwear<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.10news.com/news/1515763/detail.html |title=Channel 10 news |publisher=10news.com |date=17 June 2002 |accessdate=1 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111120184346/http://www.10news.com/news/1515763/detail.html |archivedate=20 November 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref> as they entered the school for a dance, with or without student permission, causing an uproar among students and some parents and eliciting an investigation by the school into the vice principal's conduct.<ref>[http://www.nbcsandiego.com/News/1427309/detail.html NBC San Diego] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011160853/http://www.nbcsandiego.com/News/1427309/detail.html |date=11 October 2007 }}</ref> In her defense, the vice principal said the checks were for student safety and not specifically because of the wearing of thongs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/northcounty/20020605-9999_2m5thong.html |title=> News > North County - 2 on RB High staff faulted for checks of undergarments |publisher=SignOnSanDiego.com |date=2002-06-05 |accessdate=2013-03-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/northcounty/20020616-9999_2m16thong.html |title=> News > North County - Demotion possible for assistant principal |publisher=SignOnSanDiego.com |date=2002-06-16 |accessdate=2013-03-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2002/06/18/thong-demotion.htm |title=USA Today |work=USA Today |date=18 June 2002 |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2002/06/18/national/main512654.shtml |title=CBS News |publisher=CBS News |date=11 February 2009 |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref><ref>[http://www.nbcsandiego.com/News/1429777/detail.html NBC San Diego] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071214172315/http://www.nbcsandiego.com/News/1429777/detail.html |date=14 December 2007 }}</ref> In 2003, the [[head teacher]] of a British primary school voiced her concern after learning that female students as young as 10 were wearing thong underwear to school. This incident led to a media debate about the appropriateness of thong underwear marketed to young girls.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/2943874.stm |title=Bbc (Uk) |publisher=BBC News |date=28 May 2003 |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref>
==Sports== The [[University of California]] [[4-H]] program specifically forbids "string, thong or crochet" swimsuits for women.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ucce.ucdavis.edu/files/filelibrary/2557/28364.doc |title=University of California, Davis |accessdate=1 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120208005132/http://ucce.ucdavis.edu/files/filelibrary/2557/28364.doc |archivedate=8 February 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref> For men, the dress code specifies "swim trunks only (no shorts, cut-off pants, or Speedos)." A similar policy by [[Virginia]] [[FCCLA]] bans "skimpy bikini or thong type suits" for women and specifies "swim trunks" for men ("no speedos").<ref>[http://www.me.vccs.edu/fccla/documents/DressCode_000.doc VCCS FCCLA website]{{dead link|date=January 2012}}</ref>
In 2001, [[Vicky Botwright]], then 16th seeded in women's squash circuit and dubbed the "Lancashire Hot Bot", was prohibited by the [[Women's International Squash Players Association]] (WISPA) from wearing a thong and a sports bra in the British Open Championships.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/low/other_sports/1408489.stm |title=All thong wrong @ BBC Sports Online |accessdate= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20021203211540/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/low/other_sports/1408489.stm |archivedate=3 December 2002 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
In 2004, Alexander Putnam competed in the [[London Marathon]] in a green thong and painted as a tropical tree to protest against logging in Congo.<ref>[http://www.rainforestfoundationuk.org/s-%93Mara-thong%94%20Man%20runs%20from%20Congo%20loggers "Mara-thong" Man runs from Congo loggers], Rainforest Foundation</ref>
[[Female bodybuilder]]s in America are prohibited from wearing thong or T-back swimsuits if contests are being filmed for television, otherwise they are allowed to do so by certain fitness organizations.<ref>Maria R. Lowe, ''Women of steel: female bodybuilders and the struggle for self-definition'', page 191, New York University Press, 1998, {{ISBN|0-8147-5094-X}}</ref>
==Bans== In October 2002, Florida officials banned thongs from [[Daytona Beach, Florida|Daytona Beach]] and other public beaches.<ref>{{cite newspaper|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2003-01-05-spring-break-usat_x.htm|title=Alcohol-soaked spring break lures students abroad|newspaper=USA Today|author=Donna Leinwand|date=2003-01-05}}</ref>
==Thongs for younger girls== The 2000s saw a rise in the popularity of thongs among younger girls, who have been dubbed "thong feminists" by comedian [[Janeane Garofalo]]. The trend has been attributed to pop idols like [[Britney Spears]] and [[Jennifer Lopez]].<ref name="auto"/> In 2002 [[Abercrombie & Fitch]] released a line of thong underwear targeted for girls ages 10–16, though critics pointed out that children as young as seven could fit one of the thongs.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://money.cnn.com/2002/05/22/news/companies/abercrombie/ |title=CNN Money |publisher=CNN |date=28 May 2002 |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref><ref name="JS Online">[http://www.jsonline.com/story/index.aspx?id=43941 JS Online] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071114063620/http://www.jsonline.com/story/index.aspx?id=43941 |date=14 November 2007 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E0DE3D9163BF937A15756C0A9649C8B63 |title=New York Times |work=New York Times |date=24 May 2002 |accessdate=1 January 2012 |first=Leslie |last=Kaufman}}</ref> A spokesman for A&F, Hampton Carney, stated that he could list "at least 100 reasons why a young girl would want thong underwear."<ref name="JS Online"/> This controversy spawned a great deal of free publicity for Abercrombie, including a chain letter that received wide circulation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.breakthechain.org/exclusives/aandf.html |title=Break the Chain website |publisher=Breakthechain.org |date=6 June 2002 |accessdate=1 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120122041435/http://www.breakthechain.org/exclusives/aandf.html |archivedate=22 January 2012 }}</ref> British retailer [[Argos (retailer)|Argos]] produced child-size thongs and padded [[Brassiere|bras]] for girls as young as nine, eliciting a similar response from the public.<ref>{{cite news|author=20 Feb 2007 |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2007/02/20/ngirls220.xml |title=(UK) |publisher=The Telegraph |date=20 February 2007 |accessdate=1 January 2012 |location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=This Is Money |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/pages/live/articles/news/news.html?in_article_id=363110&in_page_id=1770&in_a_source=&ito=1490 |title=(UK) |work=Daily Mail |location=UK |date=9 July 2001 |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref> [[Etam UK|Etam]], another British retailer, produced [[Sheer (textile)|sheer]] [[Top (clothing)|top]]s and thong underwear for girls of similar age.<ref>[http://www.thesun.co.uk/article/0,,2-2003140951,00.html The Sun (UK)]{{dead link|date=January 2012}}</ref> In Japan, photobooks and DVDs of underaged girls in T-back thongs has become popular as "T-back Junior Idols", which has come under scorn as a new form of child pornography.<ref>[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20070503f1.html Photos of preteen girls in thongs now big business], Japan Times</ref>
==Indecent exposure== * In August 2007 a man in Texas was arrested for [[indecent exposure]] for being naked in his own backyard. He reported that he was in fact wearing a thong and was not naked.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sanmarcosrecord.com/local/local_story_220113341.html |title=San Marcos Daily Record "Backyard exposure leads to arrest" |publisher=Sanmarcosrecord.com |date=8 August 2007 |accessdate=1 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090907090215/http://www.sanmarcosrecord.com/local/local_story_220113341.html |archivedate=7 September 2009 |df=dmy }}</ref>
==Other impacts== * A [[YMCA]] management firm has addressed thongs in dress code policy, stating (in different areas) that "thong-type wear isn't an issue." Additionally, an email from a university fitness center implied that there are safety issues ("thongs on bike seats") that would need to be addressed.<ref name="Monterey County Weekly"/> * In 2007 a man who had broken into a home wearing only a thong was sentenced to 20 years in prison for burglary and attempted rape.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wcpo.com/news/local/story.aspx?content_id=c8cbbd15-6323-407c-a4c6-ce127acc23b3|title=WPCO 9 (ABC) "Thong-Wearing Burglar Sentenced"|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071215025154/http://www.wcpo.com/news/local/story.aspx?content_id=c8cbbd15-6323-407c-a4c6-ce127acc23b3|archivedate=15 December 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.local12.com/news/local/story.aspx?content_id=310a577e-96c7-48fe-ba8c-6e3d857308c6 |title=WKRC 12 (CW) "Thong Robber Sentenced to Prison Time" |publisher=Local12.com |date=24 July 2007 |accessdate=1 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080518091250/http://www.local12.com/news/local/story.aspx?content_id=310a577e-96c7-48fe-ba8c-6e3d857308c6 |archivedate=18 May 2008 |df=dmy }}</ref> He pleaded "guilty but mentally ill" at the May trial and was sentenced in July. * In 2007 the [[Tennessee]] Department of Correction banned prison visitors from wearing thong or g-string underwear. In the words of Correction Commissioner George Little, prisoners "don't need any help getting turned on."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,290945,00.html |title=Fox News "Tennessee Bans Prison Visitors From Wearing G-Strings, Sexy Lingerie" |publisher=Fox News |accessdate=1 January 2012 |date=7 December 2011}}</ref> * After the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake|2004 Indian Ocean tsunami]], thousands of thongs were donated to relief organizations sending relief packages to [[Sri Lanka]]. These were largely discarded amongst the influx of more culturally sensitive and functional utilitarian clothing items. * During photography for [[Google Street View]], a woman in a thong was one of the images discovered that caused consternation over the project.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.seoreligion.com/google-street-view-showing-sunbathing-and-a-womans-thong.html |title=» Google Street View Showing Sunbathing and A Woman’s Thong » Blog Archive » SEO/SEM News |publisher=News.seoreligion.com |date=3 June 2007 |accessdate=1 January 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111220070543/http://news.seoreligion.com/google-street-view-showing-sunbathing-and-a-womans-thong.html |archive-date=20 December 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * In 2005, the [[Daily News (New York)|New York Daily News]] reported an incident of female United States military soldiers in Iraq stripping down to their thongs to participate in [[mud wrestling]] as an entertaining show.<ref>[http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/news/2005/02/06/2005-02-06_out_of_control_at_camp_crazy.html Female soldiers dress down & get dirty for mud romps G.I.S GONE WILD], NY Daily News {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080519003450/http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/news/2005/02/06/2005-02-06_out_of_control_at_camp_crazy.html |date=19 May 2008 }}</ref>
==Popular culture==
* In 2000, [[R&B]] singer [[Sisqó]] recorded the "[[Thong Song]]" on his ''[[Unleash the Dragon]]'' album. * Writer-director Glen Weiss made three movies titled the ''[[Thong Girl]]'', based on the comic book of the same name.<ref>{{cite web|author=Lloyd DeBerry |url=http://www.thonggirlfilms.com/ |title=Thong Girl |publisher=Thonggirlfilms.com |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref> The story of the films revolved around the Thong Girl, an independent [[superhero]]. Parts of the film were shot in [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]]'s mayor's office in 2007.<ref>[http://www.indissent.com/jan2003/lawnews.htm In Dissent] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011172530/http://www.indissent.com/jan2003/lawnews.htm |date=11 October 2007 }}</ref> * Beermaker [[Rolling Rock]] aired a commercial poking fun of male thong wearers during [[Super Bowl|Super Bowl XLI]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.splendad.com/ads/show/443-Rolling-Rock-Man-Thong-Apology |title=SplendAD |publisher=SplendAD |accessdate=1 January 2012}}</ref> * [[Shefali Zariwala]], a model in [[India]], became known as the "thong girl" for her performance in the music video of the song ''Kaanta Laga''.<ref>[http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/bangalore-times/im-indias-original-thong-girl/articleshow/1874777.cms 'I'm India's original thong girl'], Times of India</ref> The album sold two million copies and the music video became an overnight success in India.<ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/worldtoday/content/2003/s1013035.htm Indian Government censors music videos], Australian Broadcasting Corporation</ref> * In 2008, a diamond studded thong worth US$122,000 was featured in a Singapore lingerie fashion show. It had 518 brilliant-cut diamonds, totaling {{convert|30|carat|g}}, studded into the front of a black lace thong in a floral pattern, as well as 27 white gold tassels hanging off it.<ref>[http://in.reuters.com/article/oddlyEnoughNews/idINSIN13091520080403 Diamond thong shown to the throng] Reuters</ref>
